gyGbwnulZgvBXTRD5VBIDA.text: I came to Goong based on a recommendation from a friend that lives for Korean BBQ. It been while since had some so figure mix it up plus never been so why not right. I meet up with my cousin for dinner because Korean BBQ for one really makes no sense. Lol.   The menu has a nice diversity and since it was both of our first time just made things more confusing. If not AYCE I always find that get the dinner for two or three people all based on the party...safe way too go. We decided on the beef platter for two or three people. Guess most of the meats all Wagyu meats or they promote it very clearly on the menu and in the restaurant. The lists of meats might not seen like lot there was six different cuts. It more then enough food. The SIDES never seen spread that literally covered the entire table. Hell we had no room for bowl of rice or the fact ordered cold spicy noodle dish (it sounded interesting and never had cold buckwheat noodles). The sides comes with two different soups both hell of good. The kim chee soup had great depth not just kim chee heat and the egg soup or custard really really good. I could have ordered big bowl of both with side of rice be happy camper. The sides so many different ones no way going remember them all. I been to other Korean BBQ that give you lot of sides but not only the different sides but some of them nice portion not just tiny scoop or couple pieces. Really no bad side that can remember they all solid plus one was japache. Two different kinds of salad that was really refreshing way to start the meal. The first set of meats comes on a really nice display each marked for the four different cuts. Definitely give it five stars on the presentation!!! They even had tags on them all fancy. They ask you the cut want start off with first. We just went with the waitress recommendation since it was our first time. Finish off was the brisket and last one was bulgogi. Halfway through they changed the grill always something notice and look for at Korean BBQ. The more meat or protein cook that should be automatic. They did! All the meats were awesome! SoooOOOO much food. I went into cow coma by the end of it. Some sides that never got around to cause I was that full of meat. Normally say AYCE Korean BBQ only way to go. Really with the recent rush of Korean BBQ or Hot Pot places around town. Quality over quantity is the Korean BBQ way too go.   The platters may look pricey at first sight. If you break it down steal of deal in my mind. If you factor in all the sides (literally that could count for meal by itself...no joke) and the different protein. Awesome. The interior is very modern then other places around town. It little more dark on the inside with the decor. I like the way the booth and table set up with the grill. The location can be little deceiving cause it kind of hidden from DQ in front of it. I drove past it by accident. Just look for the DQ. If the parking lot full no worries just park at the one right next too it.

gCoNO5qY1droEM9Q31c_nA.text: I love Japanese and Korean BBQ, or should I say meat. The interior reminded me of Gyukaku, except Goong is sexier.   ....I will keep my review short n' sweet. I asked for some recommendation and got the following:  Pork jowl/pork toro $12 Wagyu Short Plate (Wagyu Kalbi) $11 Bulgori (Marinated thinly sliced ribeye) $11   I would say pork toro and wagyu beef were my favorites. Wagyu kalbi is a good deal for 5-6oz of meat at $11. Pork toro had lots of fat which I don't mind at all. If anything, I would use the term "juicy" instead of "fatty." Bulgogi is too sweet for me so that was a pass for me.   Lots of banchan and all were great. Nicely done bathroom also. I would come back again.

9le72pzkmDPmQXXGb2Nrbw.text: This is probably the swankiest Korean BBQ place around. They went all out making the space look sexy and modern, making it a spot worthy for a date night or just hanging out with your friends. Tables are large with plenty or space for you to spread out so you don't have to worry about bumping elbows.   They've got so many different cuts of meat that's it's overwhelming. You're better off going with one of their specials like the Goong special ($145) advertised as being good for 4-5 people. It includes wagyu rib eye, wagyu top sirloin, prime boneless short rib, wagyu chuck flat, prime flat iron, pork belly, pork jowl, marinated prime short ribs, and black tiger shrimp. With that many items it's easy to lose track of what is what. So, you just dig in. I think some of my favorites were the wagyu rib eye... or was it the top sirloin... or maybe the flat iron. I don't really know. Again, it was hard to remember what cut I was eating, but it was all good.  Another thing that was slightly confusing was the banchan... was that all you can eat? We had to request seconds of a couple dishes. And, when the bring out dishes you have to eat them family-style not individual dishes.   If you don't care about those small details, you'll love this place.

O2TmHoeUE6egpbe6i1suug.text: What's to say? The whole time we were there it felt like we were being rushed and they couldn't wait till we left. They had closed down 80% of the restaurant at 10:50pm, when they closed at midnight. The chairs were on the tables, floors mopped and nobody in sight. We walked away, double checked the closing time, still midnight, so we doubled back and finally saw a waiter. Food was good, but they asked to cook the meat for us in the kitchen (so they didn't have to clean another grill?). Our server took our order and this is my personal pet peeve, HE DID NOT WRITE DOWN THE ORDER. I don't care who you are, write it down or have a photographic memory. He forgot the drink I ordered and brought it to us as we asked for our to-go boxes. Would it of killed him to write it down? Maybe but at least my order would have been complete. All of the side dishes, and there are plenty, were wonderful, except for the weird soupy thing I did not care for, but they put them down without really explaining which dipping sauce went with what. Overall, pricey, a-la-cart and decent food but not worth the rush. *TIP - only go for the complimentary cinnamon tea at the end. It was dabomb.com.

01fOHLAlUCr7Oh9nGnBeYQ.text: Good food.  Great decor.  Comedy free of charge.  Comedy first.  Platform seating.  Shoes off, lots of bending required.  Guys, including my two Asian poker buds wearing glorified denim pantyhose AKA skinny jeans.  Just imagine a giraffe trying to sit and you get the picture.  (There are regular tables but what's the fun of that?)  Swanky.   The easiest way to describe the ambiance and what sets this KBBQ joint apart from its competitors.  From glass cases showcasing their beef to thick cut, glistening pink, raw cuts being presented on synthetic black stone slabs.  The design focuses all the attention on the food you're about to cook.  IMPORTANT, Goong advertises two types of beef, Wagyu and Prime.  To avoid disappointment understand Wagyu is a breed of cow not an indicator of quality.  The wagyu breed It is characterized by sweet flesh capable of achieving extremely fine marbling.  "Prime" denotes USDA prime and DOES reflect the marbling regardless of the breed.   Not all Wagyu is USDA Prime or higher.  Choose your cut based on the flavor you want to enjoy.  Tip:  Opt for a set.  Sets include all the banchan (including a salad), steamed egg, a choice of soup for the table and a good cross selection of their proteins.  Add additional proteins ala carte if you think you need more food.  A few mushrooms are provided for grilling.  No additional veg.  Standard KBBQ cuts.  Beef cut thicker than most places the quality very good (USDA choice or higher).  Pork has a good amount of fat that crisps up nicely.  Marinades tend to be on the sweet side.  Regardless of set, be sure to order some pork jowl.  Sweet, porky goodness.   Beef lovers, it's all about the wagyu short plate.  Lots of internal fat.  Sweet beefy goodness.  Unlike most KBBQ places, you are in full control of your grill.  Servers will offer to help to start you off but thereafter, it's all you.    KBBQ is stepping up its game in Vegas and Goong is right at the forefront.

PnnWv9IpstZ6LMtOy7_Q9A.text: Our server HS Kim was awesome! The decor is so cute. Very Modern-chic! We have always been to all you can eat places but this....this is QUALITY! hueZmLFcG6t_dEuUL-fEzg.text: I have become somewhat of a Korean barbecue connoisseur as of lately. I have tried several popular locations throughout Las Vegas, San Diego, LA and  Honolulu. I thought I had found the one place that I really liked until I tried this place!  The food, although smaller portions than what I'm used to, was fresh and tasty without being too salty or overly spiced.  Even as we asked for more of a particular side we were told that the kitchen had run out because we ate it all!   The service here is amazing. Comparatively to all the other Korean restaurants that I have tried the service in this location is by far the best I've ever received.  In most other Korean restaurants it has become the norm for me to be told how to eat, when to eat, and to be questioned why I was mixing certain spices and sauces to accommodate the flavors of my meal. The service is usually very abrupt, pushy and cold.  Here, I felt as though I was given the opportunity to eat the way I want to eat. And to cook my food the way I want to cook my food. The entire time our server was extremely attentive to our needs as though we were his only guests. He was always there to make sure we had everything that we needed. And didn't question our choices.  He was also made recommendations suggestions to help make our experience that much better.  I cannot wait to go back again!

0GCHt6QHj24RMhITVaAIzw.text: Been at this place couple times and every time still like the first time. Meat quality is perfect! even without marinated. You had my 5* but your server messed up!!!!   Ordered a bottle of soju me both me and cousin, I.D. check! of course no complain on that. I'm 22 and my cousin is 28. The server looked at my I.D. and gave it back, then looked at my cousin's then surprisingly asked him " You're older than him( who is me )?!?!? ". Deep down in my heart, I died a little bit :( only a bottle of soju you dont have to make me feel that way :(( .   Just a funny story I wanna share but love this place, will always come back.

1ki-nOGj_UR_LKuE2OC28Q.text: A very embarrassing experience for me entertaining friends.   With a large convention in town i had friends from 4 different states in Vegas and i thought what a great way to have a community meal than Korean BBQ. I decided on Goong because i simply wanted my guests to have the best experience possible with quality, service, and of course the presentation of the space. The one positive note i will make to start is the layout and decor is nothing to complain about, but that's where the positive ends. Our server was certainly new (he mentioned it), but i do not think his lack of service was completely his fault. He began the meal by cooking the meat, even before we had banchan or rice on the table (a bit odd). When i asked about the banchan, the server had no idea what i was talking about. I don't expect you to be Korean (although it helps) to work at a Korean restaurant but maybe at least learn what you are serving or should be serving at a minimum. When he finally did go back to get our banchan, the meat was then left to over cook where we then stepped in and cooked it ourselves for fear of ruining meat. This act of overcooking our meat by our server was happening all night as he was constantly running back and forth trying to keep the banchan flowing and the meal moving in the right direction. I typically cook when going to KBBQ, but i wanted not to this time so i can converse with my friends whom i haven't seen in years. Unfortunately, this wasn't able to happen because our server lacked the efficiency by himself to handle the table. The restaurant had only 3-5 other tables, so i am unsure why addition assistance didn't come from some of the other staff just standing around. The server also didn't mention what he was cooking, so there was a lot of confusion if there was meat that had yet to be served to us. I later learned that he didn't mention the meats because he wasn't aware of what he was actually serving, similar to him not knowing what banchan was. The end of the meal was the worst moments because my guests were still looking forward to eating but the meat stopped flowing. Lots of confusion and 10 minutes of me getting up and addressing the staff determined that 3 orders of meat was lost in the service and they brought them out after to serve. 2 of my guests were no longer interested in eating at that point, and the other 2 i am sure ate it so that it didn't go to waste as they could sense my frustration throughout the entire meal. Difference in quality? Not terribly different to some of the other spots i have been, and certainly not worth the lack of service displayed here. Couple that with our server overcooking it and you get the idea, it's simply not worth the efforts or money. Never again. I will prefer to order the meat, and have them bring it out to me and ill cook for my guests and keep the flow as it should be.   To the management  - Think about training your employees to at a minimum knowing the menu. Basic knowledge on what the word banchan is or what Bulgogi might be is day 1 of learning i would think.  - Think about having a support for the servers cooking. A banchan dish is empty and the server asks if we would like more. He can then let the support that is helping the floor grab it so the cook doesn't leave the table so often.  - Think about having the server know the meats, and mention it when they are cooking. This way the table knows they are getting exactly what they ordered, and chances of having to stop the meal to figure out what was lost wouldn't happen.

YDA8eNOcBRkPMsx3XpDLMQ.text: This place is fantastic! Beautiful decor and layout. I ordered the Wagyu combination. The meat was delicious and beautifully cooked by our waitress. She was very attentive and didn't make us feel uncomfortable like you might get as some places. The portion said 2-3 people, but we could have easily gotten away with 4 people and left full. We also got a side of the kimchi fried rice with steak (because we thought the combo might not be enough). We couldn't finish it, but I would have licked that plate clean.  I'll for sure be back! Maybe next time with more people.

fDRD3qD4jk46symt1r-jvQ.text: Stopped in here for lunch a couple days ago.  Bulgogi and a large sample of sides made for a great meal.   Service and atmosphere were on point.

ZGzvJqnZ8jzKlx04Oemp1Q.text: I visited two Korean bbq places one day apart and it was my first time at a Korean bbq. This was the second place I tried. This place was a lot more upscale. They had high quality meats here. The beef cuts were wagyu and very tender and flavorful. The side dishes were tasty. They had a bigger than usual drink menu that offered cocktails and wine and not just soju and beer. Be careful of your clothes though, because the grease splatters from the grill. My favorite thing was the cinnamon tea they brought out as dessert at the end. Overall I enjoyed this place more than the other Korean bbq place, but I don't think I'd have a craving for this. The atmosphere was cold. We were a group of 8 that had never tried Korean bbq before so we didn't know much about how the menu worked or what the side dishes were. We were asking a lot of questions, but the waitress didn't talk much or even try to explain anything. I only heard her talk when she said the meat was ready.

v90pAzHefmB7ohioXrCOPA.text: This place is all a la carte and not an all you can eat beef buffet. They have separate items you can order and also "sets" which is a pork set and a beef set. The pork is cheaper than the beef but the amount is roughly the same. The smaller set can feed 2-3 people (or 3-4 females because of the sheer amount of side dishes). The larger set can feed about 4 to 5 people.   I think the only difference is whether your party is super hungry or is looking for quality. All you can eat won't have the best quality but it's a great option if you want to try different types of meat and Korean marinates. If you only want to eat a certain type and you want to get a better quality than a place like this restaurant is a better pick.  They have excellent staff and friendly hostess. Interior looks good and bathroom clean!

fi9MeyrmKrIFs8T08MAGtQ.text: I've been wanting to try out this place after driving by it so many times. It's easy to find right off Rainbow & Robindale.  We had the option to sit at a booth or the traditional style tables where you sit down on a pillow with no shoes on. We chose the traditional way to have a different experience. For a party of 3 , we ordered the beef platter and spent about 70$ altogether here. Other reviewers said the portions are small but I disagree. It was a lot of food for three people ! Meat quality is very good and there was tons of side dishes.  The servers cook for you all the way through for each meat in a prompt manner which was nice. With all the KBBQ restaurants on this side of town , this one is definitely up there (although I like Hobak a bit more due to better dessert selection and service).

aqtVfXf2N2MxgjbD3cG8gg.text: We have tried several different Korean BBQ places in the Vegas area (even other 4-5 star establishments)...and I would say this place is very good!  Lots of sides but the best part is the quality of the meats.  Just amazing! Service is great as well.  This is our go-to place for Korean BBQ.  We continue to come here and the quality does not change...and service is always good.  We did come on Valentine's Day as well...they were very busy, but still managed to give us good service.  I would say that day wasn't a 10 (like all the other times), but they were very busy...and we didn't mind because the staff all looked very focused....they were trying.   Anyway...definitely recommend this place to everyone.  For us, we bring all of our visiting friends...pretty much the first recommendation we give to most asking about Korean BBQ.  Enjoy!!

zteeATZEgVuEPy1QeM19Vg.text: Came here last Sunday for dinner with a large group. Overall, the food was great and so was the service.   The place was nice. It was large, had good decor, a good atmosphere for a Korean bbq place, and most importantly - clean. They had traditional Korean tables in addition to booths and side rooms for larger parties.   We were a group of 17, and we ordered 3 Goong Special Platters. All of the meats included were excellent, especially the wagyu ribeye and the marinated prime short ribs. There was plenty of the meat to go around and the side dishes were good. The included soups that we selected as part of the order were very flavorful.   The service was excellent: friendly, accommodating, and attentive. While cooking, our server would indicate to us when the meats were medium-rare for those of us in the group that wanted the meats that way. As an added bonus for our large party, they gave us a free platter of meat sushi (slices of meat on top of rice) which was also very good. The meat sushi bonus was a nice touch and much appreciated by our party.   There was plenty of food for all us and the entire group all left Goong full and satisfied. I would definitely recommend Goong and most assuredly will be back.   4 1/2 Stars

4KyLE2bhItKaMfhQnAZ3Xw.text: By far my favorite Korean BBQ restaurant anywhere.  The best ever. The ambiance is great and the staff is terrific.

CXtHdkfga7M5FEtN4_DcPA.text: Something new for Vegas as far as Korean BBQ! This isn't AYCE which means they are more focused on the quality of the meat. Now let me start by saying that you are paying more, but the quality definitely matches up! I have no complaints about that, but if you're looking at portion/quality vs price.. then it be a bit disappointing. The portion is a bit smaller than I thought it would be. When you order the combos it's only good for 2 good people at most. If you're a big eater.. you might not leave satisfied. You won't leave hungry, but you won't feel the full satisfaction. When I last came here they did not have the proper grill to cook briskets and the pork belly as the fire quickly burned the briskets. I'm sure they changed that by now. The bonchon(side dish) was good and the server was very attentive!   The seating is different as it's a bit more traditional Korean! You sit down which many people are not used to. In Korea it's normal for people to sit while they eat, so this was a nice experience for me.   I enjoyed the food and the service, but only see myself coming here if I have guests whom I want to take to a good quality BBQ spot. If I just wanna fulfill my usual Korean BBQ cravings I rather go to an AYCE and pay a little less for more although I may be sacrificing the quality.

XyHKn8B7I-5AygVxvFJHLA.text: Second time here in less than a week and like our first visit, everything here is the best. Excellent Service and food.

photos.caption: Photo of Goong Korean BBQ Restaurant - Las Vegas, NV, United States

e5vOG_TqJNsNAhzRuMNlRA.text: I'm always shocked to find a great restaurant that is virtually empty at dinner.  But, such is Las Vegas in December on a Tuesday.  First, the meat.  Three of us shared the beef platter, a series of 5 increasingly fatty, non-marinated cuts followed by Bulgogi.  Between the staff cooking the meat and you taking pieces when they're done to your liking, it works really well.  The first 5 cuts need some seasoning post-cook and you can choose from two flavored salts or a soy-based dipping sauce.  The quality of the beef was outstanding.  Second, the sides.  There's about a dozen or so little dishes that come with the platter and they're really, really good, and you can ask for seconds (maybe more) on the ones you like best. Great variety - kimchi, noodles, two salads, raw vegetables, pickled vegetables, radish and a bunch of others that were hard to figure out exactly what they were other than delicious.  Also with the beef platter comes a choice of soup - we got tofu and it was great - and four small pancakes that they cook prior to the beef.    All together, the beef platter for 2-3 with the sides and the soup could easily serve 4 adults.  The staff are very helpful and attentive and the interior is clean and mid-2000 modern.  Overall, a great dining experience and a fantastic Korean BBQ joint.

IR8V1H-qRSQGEE1Yj39Rmg.text: Nice ambience. Love the modern classy decor. By far the nicest Korean BBQ place we have been to in Vegas. Friendly & attentive staff, that cooks the meat for tourists. Good quality meat & sides and portions are good too. Although it's not ayce you still get a bang for your buck.

They carry both Korea beer and Japanese beer, server very good Koran barley tea.  We got a lot dishes like kimchi, fish cake , slice round pink radish, the radish is so good for beef. All comes with the dinner set.  We got very good quality beef, pork belly, a sweet Korean girl, always come help us to cook.   A good experience here, we will come back for sure

OT-xWg_E7dr0bUZTotPjJQ.text: We came here last Sunday at around 3pm and we were basically the only customers at that time. We ordered the beef combo and it was enough food for us. The interior of the restaurant looks amazing and the dishes/bowls that they use here are very nice too. However I find it very odd that they use those disposable chopsticks despite how nice other things are.   The girl server was very nice and attentive. She asked us which meat we would prefer to grill first and let us eat at our own pace. However halfway through our meal they switched to a guy server and service started to go downhill. He didn't ask us which meat we wanted to grill first and he was grilling everything very fast and we felt rushed. There were like two table eating in the entire restaurant so I don't understand the need for him to rush us out. Overall food tasted just okay/average/almost at the level you get at ayce places. I have tasted much better Korean bbq elsewhere.   Now comes the worst part...I started to feel extremely sick at around 10-11pm that day. I had really bad watery diarrhea the entire night and had been throwing up until 4am. I felt really weak the next day and had to miss school. I had many exams that week and all I can say is I don't think i performed as well as I hoped. The diarrhea lasted around 3 days.  I'm pretty sure I got food poisoning from this place because that's the only meal I ate that day.

3y2COZ57ziHWQ9OuaDVWyA.text: Best KBBQ I've had in Vegas. Our server Sunjoo was helpful and took great care of us. We were pretty intimidated by the fancy vibe but she made us feel very welcome. well be back for sure!

RZQCwUmJTahKRCiowmP7KA.text: This is by far the best Korean restaurant in Vegas. It is not all you can eat. But it is great quality meat. The banchan or side dishes are amazing. Everything is fresh and flavors are amazing. We had the Goong Set Platter and it was awesome.  The Goong set platter comes with a mixture of wagging and prime beef, marinated pork and even black tiger shrimp.   We also had a few of the cold noodle dishes which were awesome.  JunHee was a great server. Food was out quick and our water and tea were always filled.   The price definitely justifies the quality of the product.   Goong was a great choice and our bellies are better for coming here.

ry-1hKS5rT57LBheYRAjsg.text: Tried this place last night after seeing it a few weeks ago. Amazing! The only complaint I have is the menu needs better English descriptions. Our server was extremely helpful in explaining the menu though, so it's not a big deal. We had floor seating where you take off your shoes. Comfy cushions and it's not difficult to get in or out of the tables.   We ordered the wagyu beef platter. It's supposed to be for 2-3 people, but I would say it could feed more like 4. The platter came with a ton of different sides: kimchi, onion salad, green salad, black beans, squid, seafood pancake, tiny little pancake that had jalapenos, radish, eggplants, soup, and more that I can't recall. Then there was the beef with a large variety of cuts. Two types of seasoning to use and the usual soy sauce to accompany the food. We also had Korean wine, which was so tasty!   Service was amazing. They helped us cook our food as needed, and we're generally amazing. The manager came to talk with us after our meal, which I thought was so great. The the price was amazing. About $140 for everything; beef, sides, and many drinks. I will definitely be coming back soon!

1S_WEdd4C1y241-xZ9E_Tw.text: This place was really good! Food was great actually! Some of the best sides and appetizers I've had so far at Korean BBQ. The place feels a little fancy but I think it was actually rather "affordable". We got one of the meat combos, it was 85 dollars came with a bunch of really awesome looking meats and sides. It says it feeds 4 to 5 people, we we're 3 and a baby and  we all left happy and satisfied. It's different than other Korean BBQs I've been to, they put the meats on the grill for you and like come by and flip them and tell you when they are ready. Took me a sec to get used to that, but honestly the meats were all cooked better than when we've done it on our own haha. I felt like the service is super super attentive. The only thing is, they didnt give us like empty plates to like put the meats on when they are done. I feel like we were supposed to eat them off the grill, but they give you a million sides and apps and salads ( not complaining) and then the meats and they cool them one by one so we kinda felt like rushed a lil bit. I have a baby so I am pretty accupied a lil bit to like hurry up and eat the meats, and at one point they told us our meats were getting burnt haha. But we asked for plates and got them and problem was solved and it was smooth sailing after that. And they have soda by the can and even their tea was canned or bottled and I hate that at any place. But they do give you ice water in cute little cups and this awesome cinnamon tea at the end of your meal. This place was great in both food and service. We will totes be back. Really happy we tried this place. Super super yummy.

j3aJQYX8GkPBXeOuEYEQpg.text: Came here with my family visiting from California. The food was fresh. We ordered 2 meat platters for a party of 5 it was just right along with all the sides. The side salad had the best ginger dressing which was refreshing to have in between all the meat that was served. Will be back again soon.

QREEs-iiWJHGk9yJHRcI6w.text: "Enjoy when you can, and endure when you must." - Johann Wolfgang von Goethe  This is one of my favorite spots in Vegas for KBBQ. This isn't AYCE and you pay more for the better quality... But the fact that you're actually getting decent quality cuts of meat instead of the utter crap that is rampant at your standard KBBQ restaurant is well worth it.   My love and I came in with Philip T. and Ayumi K. to share a feast of meat and a surprisingly wonderful assortment of banchan...after all, who doesn't love a feast of meat with wonderful sides? The four of us shared the Goong Special Platter that consisted of wagyu ribeye, wagyu top sirloin, wagyu chuck flat, prime boneless short rib, prime flat iron, pork belly, pork jowl, marinated prime short ribs, black tiger shrimp, and a choice of soup for $145. The meat portions were hearty, and It was more than enough food due to the ample and delightfully tasty banchan. Not a brad price per person with four of us...though if you aren't keen on enjoying great banchan side dishes the meat-centric individuals may only want to split this serving three ways.  Our server cooked the meats for us...he was attentive and accommodated our cooking temperatures nearly all of time. The hoods were good, minimizing the notion upon walking out that you just bathed in Korean BBQ...a huge plus! We shared a couple bottles of wine and still walked away at a reasonable price for the four of us.

OfxoIU9NIXqUfSesI9ACjQ.text: We went here for our pre-dessert trip. I like meat...lots of it. Though this is not an AYCE KBBQ place, they do have platters: Pork Platter for $42 for 2-3 people, Beef platter for $65 for 2-3 people. I eat for 2 people all the time anyway so, the platter options were perfect. Our tables was covered in small plates of ban chan: kim chee, squid, potato salad, chives, salad, noodles, fish cakes, pickled radish, broccoli, carrots, and other veggies.  Beef Platter: Prime rib eye, wagyu top sirloin, prime chuck flat, prime flat iron, thinly sliced prime brisket, and marinated thinly sliced rib eye. It also comes with mushrooms. The cuts of beef were tender. They'll give you a side of sauce and two kinds of salt so you can flavor your meats accordingly to your own preference. It's a lot of food.  It's a nicer KBBQ restaurant and not uber casual. You can get a regular table if you're not doing KBBQ, a tatami-esque area, or a table with a grill. The service is good. Attentive without being annoying.

goD9mCmGTB03uvAfNOX5rA.text: This place is legit. Top quality meats, plenty of sides, attentive staff. Try the wagyu platter, it's amazing! One of the best KBBQ joints in town. Worth the trek across town.

0u9jG138M4mexoZSnzAqHA.text: This is our favorite date night outing. It is near our home, I love Korean BBQ, and it is a classy place with wonderful service. The restaurant is spacious, clean and boasts a modern design infused with traditional Korean decorative touches. This is NOT cheap or a place akin to AYCE joints, so I would not recommend if you are on a budget. Another complaint I saw was that the servers are "overly involved" in terms of cooking the meat. I appreciate that because it alleviates the smoke, improperly cooked meat, oh-crap moments where they have to run over to a table and douse it in water. It makes for a relaxing, semi interactive experience.  They have an extensive beverage menu and we always opt for Chum Chubum Soju because I love anything that tastes like peach. It is reasonably priced at $12 for a bottle and it is more than enough between the two of us. We opt for the Beef Combination Platter ($65) which includes prime rib eye, wagyu top sirloin, prime chuck flat, prime flat iron, thinly sliced prime brisket and marinated thinly sliced rib eye. The banchan is pretty standard consisting of kimchi, spicy radish, soybean sprout, Oi Muchim (spicy cucumber salad), watercress namul, fried tofu, etc. One most certainly gets their money's worth, but make sure to come hungry! I have always found the service to be consistent, courteous and accommodating. I also don't mind the extra hand in helping cook my meat to perfection.

I9EmdoIlA4PwkOdYlZMfiA.text: I love the decor of this restaurant, so spacious, clean and with Korean  style seating..  Good for date night!!   hubby and I choose the $65 marinated combo for 2/3 people and it's perfect amount of meats.. The combo comes with steam egg(very bland) and 3 types of soup to choose from.  I got the seafood and it was just OK, but had a lot of seafood in it especially octopus .. too chewy for me.. hehe    They cook all the meats for you which is nice.. I love their banchan(side dishes) 10 WOW!! That's probably the most I've had at a Korean bbq.  All of the banchan was very tasty and delicious, especially the fish cakes.  Except the salads 2 types, it wasn't good. I'm NOT into cold and sour bland soup, I find it weird tasting.. it's like drinking sour water, and every restaurant I go to they serve that and I would tell them I don't want it...  We came at 5pm on Saturday and there and it was pretty much empty, I wonder if it even get busy later .    Definitely will come back again!!

d3-ixV-K8bO081woX1kEEg.text: I've never been to Korean bbq but this was amazing. The sweet soy bulgiogi chicken and the wagu brisket were phenomenal. The veggies were delicious. I don't know what the side dishes were but half of them were pretty good including the pink pickled reddish, seaweed salad looking noodles, kimchi cake, greens with a ranch sauce, rice, and onion salad. Dipping sauce was tasty. A few of the pickled sides were extra bitter and the potato ball was somewhat bland. Overall amazing taste and great value, enough food for two people for one all you can eat price.

Ad6RIGpIAADzkENC3nTN5Q.text: I have been here several times and while the quality of meat and food in general is excellent the service aspect could use some work.  I have been here a few times and I can say Goong definitely has the best quality of any of the Korean BBQ restaurants I've been to in town.  They always have a nice variety of side dishes and their entrees are reasonably priced.  They have a few platters for parties of 2-3 or more which are great.  I especially enjoy the Beef Platter.  It's $65 and servers 2-3 people.  They have a pork one as well which is $45.    The downfall to this restaurant and for my experience is the aggressiveness of the servers.  Each time I've been here with my Korean friend the servers will rip the utensil out of her hand when she is flipping the meat.  At any other restaurant they let you cook it however one time when we came here the server even said something as she was clearly upset that he kept taking the tongs from her.  Today we had only been seated for a few minutes and we were asked 3 times if we were ready to order.  We clearly were not.    If the interpersonal skills were better this place would be top knotch.

JyiuzZJJt5ZdtjfohuZm5Q.text: This place had a 4.5 star average, when Honey Pig elsewhere in town only has 3 stars, so I decided to give it a try--a horrible decision.  Upon sitting down, I overheard other customers speaking in Japanese, which gave me high hopes. I read through the menu, which had English/Romanized text, Hangul, Japanese, and ...I believe Cantonese. It may have been Simplified Chinese but I cannot remember. One section of the menu... perhaps the standard Barbecue section... had one sentence explanations of the order in English. A different section, the Marinated Barbecue section, had one line explanations in Hangul. This inconsistency troubled me.  Before we decided on our order, the busman who seemed very happy with his job was cleaning the table opposite ours. Each platter he emptied out and replaced in his cart produced a loud, obnoxious clunk. Perhaps this means the hardware is of good quality.  We attempted to order lunch specials, but because we were dining on Sunday afternoon, we could not order the Monday through Friday lunch specials. Instead, we ordered the beef short rib (kalbi) and bulgogi from the normal menu.  Because Goong is a normal Korean BBQ restaurant without an all you can eat menu, comparing volume is USUALLY out of the question. However, this only holds True when the a la carte location provides quality tiers above the smorgasbord option.  The appetizers came in plenty, as I expected. However, I did not expect to receive five different types of radishes, accounting for more than half the plates. My sub claims the kimchi was good. I dislike chili so I didn't try it. We agreed despite coming in spicy, shaved, sour, pickled, and grated varieties, the different forms of radish did not fulfill our appetizer demands. The remaining appetizers included spicy toufu, sesame oil noodle (I forget the name,) salt and pepper salad, and some kind of mashed potatoes. I expected something including fish or egg, but nothing of the sort arrived.  The white rice came in a small bowl. I remembered seeing "Extra Rice ... 2" on the menu, and my heart sinking at the thought. The meat also came in small, but reasonable amounts. You are paying about eight or nine times as much for the meat here as you are at the supermarkets down the street, but they marinated it for you and included a lot of appet...radish. They will also turn the grill on for you, place the meat on it for you, and repeatedly come to turn the meats over and cut it into bite size pieces for you, even if you have gigantic mouths and prefer five times the bite size they cut, like me. They will turn the grill off for you before the meat is well done.  The bulgogi was ... bulgogi. The marinade was fairly weak, but tastable. The meat quality was good, a little bit better than Honey Pig. The kalbi was an interesting cut--unlike the multi-bone with bone fragment hell you get any other place you order kalbi, it was one rib, and the slices of meat above it. The marinade was ... almost absent, but I THINK it was marinated in something. Perhaps it was just the remaining drip from the bulgogi, I am not sure.  At this stage of the meal, we were slowly becoming radish, when I ran out of rice. My heart sank as it remembered the number two and my eyes tried to justify its connection to the small bowl of rice, but luckily the radish across from me let me have the remaining rice. With it, I managed to finish off the meats to perfect my meat-radish balance.  In the end, there is no reason not to drive the extra miles to go to Honey Pig and eat slightly lower quality food (with better selection and, last I checked, 24 hour operation) and get more satisfaction for your pennies.  I will next try Doh down the street, no matter what Yelp says about it.  We paid the check, and on the way out I greeted the hostess with a prominent and thankful "Xiexie!" and left, never to return.

vzeVxAA-2u8pmVRo-ivd2A.text: After a long Saturday of working, running errands & shopping. We decided to try out Goong because I had it bookmarked for awhile and heard about it through my Korean friends.  Upon entering the restaraunt we were greeted with a warm "ann-yeong-hasayo," Hello in Korean and slight bow. First impression was the formality of the staff and the ambience of the restaraunt. It was very modern and classy compared to other Korean restaraunts in the valley. Seating arrangement was a cool aspect of Goong, allowing you to enjoy a meal on the floor with more of a traditional flare or the option of being seated at regular table. Our server for the evening was, Jun. He was very friendly and knowledgeable with the menu. His service left a lasting impression on us. If you ever get the chance to try this place out. I reccomend him as a server.   Now on to the food, this is was something we were not accustomed to since most of our experience with Korean BBQ is usually AYCE, with the exception of Hobak which is why I haven't got around to writing a review for Hobak yet. The reason is because I wanted to compare 2 of the most popular Korean BBQ restaraunts in Vegas.   We opted for the Beef Platter which was good for 2-3ppl. From the very first pieces to the end was simply delicious. The quality of each meat was seasoned just right especially the Bulgogi. However I really enjoy the Prime Flat Iron and Prime Rib Eye. Those cuts of meat were juicy and flavorful especially when paired with the dipping sauce that was provided. The variety of banchan(side dishes) were fresh and delicious. We also got the Kimchi Fried Rice and that was very good with a perfect balance of spices and heat.   Overall we had great time! By far the best Korean Restaraunt in Las Vegas!  / Thank You Jun and the staff of Goong for a cool experience!

sXu63H_QQUMzXDJglcphKQ.text: It's a sad day, when I have to fulfill my duty to other Yelpers, and lower a rating on what has always been a quality experience, but it is my duty to keep everyone informed.   Recently, we took my mother in law and other family to Goong. Just 6 of us in all.   Bottom line; They were busy and didn't have enough staff to cover, so the Manager acted as our Server for the evening. Very noble, but besides giving very poor service, he added 20% to our check for a tip, based on 6 people at the table.  The European tradition adopted by our American culture is to put 15-18% for a party of 8 or more.   Though we may have given a 20% tip for service or tradition, this gentleman, who comes from the Korean culture, where tipping is very rare, had no business deciding this on his own.  The food is still good and it is a real hassel parking in that busy center. I can't say the food disappointed. However, the fact that the Manager had the nerve to insure that he "pocket" a 20% tip, is reason enough for me to stop going to this place.  Why 2 stars and not 1 star?  I figured if I make it 1 star, readers will think I was just out for revenge. 2 stars, might get people to think about what I wrote, and know if they still go there, "they were warned".

They bring out at least 6-8 bowls of different things inside and don't tell you what's what. Unless you've eaten Korean BBQ before you would have no idea what they are in those bowls.  Price: pretty comparable to other Korean BBQ restaurants in town. Maybe a bit pricier but it is worth it for where and how the restaurant looks.  Cleanliness: extremely clean again compared to other Korean BBQ restaurants in town that I have been to.  Quality: is good. Could provide a bit more meat for what you pay for but overall it's tasty. It's hard to drink if you're not used to it. They have a full drink menu with beer, wine, shoju, and more.  DINING: Their portions are a little smaller than other restaurants and they do not have all you can eat. Their meat is very low quality and very tough to chew. They serve everything with the small Korean side dishes. I like this place because they give a lot of side dishes.Their menu is pretty full with all your favorite Korean bbq dishes so everyone is sure to have something they will enjoy. Super excited that this place has the short rib and dikon soup because it is a rare dish to find. Everything is honestly over-priced here.  DESSERTS: mochi mochi mochi!!!

I3VzVUzwk5eH99MVkFLJ1w.text: Several months earlier, my department head at work brought me and a couple coworkers to Goong over lunch, and I remember the food here was awesome, so I decided to take my wife here. The place is very clean, and well designed around Korean culture. In the center of the restaurant, they have tables raised just off the floor. We were seated on the outer edge, at the tables for 4, and these are placed at normal height (for Americans). They played american music, and the young Korean staff could be heard singing along quietly from our table. They were in very good spirits. My wife and I ordered the marinated beef, chicken, and pork dinner for two. I also ordered a Hite beer, and they brought out a large bottle of beer, which was like 22 ounces I think. My wife ordered the Korean raspberry wine, of which she gave me a taste, and was delicious. They brought out several sides, among which were Korean glass noodles, to dried radish, and kimchi (which I love), seafood soup, mixed veggies (with its own dipping sauce that was sweet and hot) and dipping sauces for the meats, and a few others that I can't remember the names of. Your table gets literally full of little side dishes. And you're picking off these while the meat is cooking. The staff cooks the meat for you, (probably for health code reasons) so they are frequently at your table. They cook the meats on a grill that comes up through the center of your table. They even change the grill halfway through the dinner so we had a fresh one when they started the chicken. The service was above expectations, and we were never wondering where a person is if we needed anything. The food itself was absolutely phenomenal. They nailed the marinades on each of the meats. The sides were all delicious as well, even though we both had our favorites. At the very end of the meal, they brought out two cinnamon teas in tiny little cups. Just enough to taste, but not too much because you are so full from the meal that you can't drink the whole thing, which you will be. There was so much meat that by the time we got to the last pork protein, we could not eat another bite. The staff reassured us that this is normal, and boxed up the remaining items. The price was just over $90 for my wife and me, and honestly I expected it to be more considering the sheer volume of food we got. I remember we were saying that we could have easily had brought two more people with us to eat everything that they brought out. I would rate this among the most exceptional dining experiences we've had in the Vegas valley, and we will definitely be going again.

a_OZKlTekQtKT7MsGvsZqA.text: Very solid Korean BBQ. My only standard is Hobak, because I'm new to the K BBQ scene and I'm not sure it's fair to compare the two but life's not fair.  The food was great.  We shared the Goong Special Platter - Waygu everything, short ribs, shrimp.  Incredibly tender but not pre-marinated so not as flavorful as I like.  Unlike Hobak, Goong seems to focus more on the sides (13 in total) and less on the meat.  I'm typically looking for the meat sweats when I have Korean BBQ.    Service was attentive, if not overly friendly. My only real complaint is that there is no ambiance. It's very antiseptic, like eating in a fluorescent-lit cafeteria.  We had a group of 7 and reserved a booth so we could have back support. If you don't wear orthotics, you might be interested in the cute little tables you sit around cross-legged and perhaps the ambiance is a little better over there.  If you are in the neighborhood, Goong is worth a trip.

JcVuRmyXGBvhxs6HKvi0Bg.text: BS +++ This is not an AYCE location which is new for me since I'm used to NYC Korean bbq locations to be almost buffet style.  I been to Gen here in Vegas and it wasn't that impressive. This fufu-modern Jap-Korean bbq spot is the bomb.  The chic layout is definitely a plus as you walk in.   They have benches with cute pillows you can relax on Japanese style or you can ask for the a nice booth seating.  They wait staff are very attentive and super nice.  I love how they cook for you to ensure meat is not overcooked.  We ordered the beef bbq platter (it looks small but it's a lot), Pork belly, sirloin and green tea and strawberry ice cream mochi.  The barrage of side dishes was a lot and they even gave three rice bowls.  I didnt think it was a lot but for $133 it was a steal.  They even offered a cinnamon green tea sweet drink on the house.  The experience was fun especially the clubby music they were playing but not that loud that you had to scream at each other.  The lighting was bright that you didn't have to squint while searching for cooked meat.  The meat was fresh and clean.  Nothing looked old or marinated to the point that you couldn't tell if the meat was fresh.  Overall it was a great filling experience.  I would highly recommend this place to any foodie.  Be forewarned it is still a Korean bbq spot.  So don't wear your nice clothes that you don't want to smell like meat for weeks.  I don't just endorse spots for freebies.  So come down to this beautiful strip of stores and eat S Rainbows legit good eats.  Location is CLEAN, PROFESSIONAL. ORGANIZED Staff are COURTEOUS, FRIENDLY, CALMING, PROFESSIONAL Parking lot is SHARED but SPACIOUS Restrooms DID NOT GO IN Food WAS AMAZEBALLS!  * Boomsauce scale. BW = Dis $@% is BASURA! (Garbage). Not recommended. BS = it's just O.K. (experience) BS+ = Yo! I like this place. BS++= That's Whoa! This place good. BS+++= Dayumm! This place is fkn DOPE!

q2mDGbuJwjbCO42x9R-H3A.text: Solid Korean BBQ with unique seating options   Service Generally pretty friendly and attentive. Meat was brought promptly and cooked well for us at the table. Extra sides were gladly provided as well on request.   Ambiance  Fairly standard Korean BBQ place, though they have some unique tables where you take off your shoes and sit on cushions (we tried this). It sounds odd but was actually comfy. If you do this, though, get a table on the end. If you're in the middle there's nowhere to rest your back. That looked not so comfy.   Food You can order packages of assorted meats or al la carte (we did this as we wanted kalbi which didn't seem to be in the packages). They bring tons of amazing sides first as is Korean tradition. Then they come prepare the meat for you. We had a spicy pork and kalbi. Both were very good though kalbi was not quite as tender as we would've liked. Generally the meat seemed of good quality. We noticed "martinis" on the menu in assorted flavors for $6. Seemed like a good deal, so we tried a peach and a grapefruit. They tasted like juice. I don't think there was booze in them at all. Well, they were delicious juices anyway.   Mojo  Overall a good Korean BBQ establishment with quality meat and good service and unique seating options. If you go, ask if the martini has booze in it before you order :)

RS5CFcAT0rgGwgKpx_i7Fg.text: Vegas is far from a city barren to KBBQ spots. But tucked away in Southwest Vegas is one of my new favorite spots for good quality and service joints for when you want to take on the meat sweats!  Goong has been around for awhile now but I finally was able to try it with some friends this month after hearing pretty good things about it. We opted for the premium set for 5 people and boy oh boy, it is A LOT OF FOOD!   You have your wide array of ban chan side dishes including kim chee, bean sprouts, side salads and you get to choose what kind of soups you want to accompany your meal. But the meat is where the meal really shines. It's great quality and flavor meat, much better than many of the places I've tried on Spring Mountain. I particularly really enjoyed the short rib.   The staff was always proactive about changing out our grill and moving us along in our meal without the feeling of rushing us out.  Yes, it is a tad on the pricier end but you certainly get what you pay for!

zOiUxlxojfWUwaXC7ie1Eg.text: I like this place because it seems like you are entering an upscale Korean restaurant.  The staff delivers friendly service throughout our dining experience.  We never had to cook our food at our table. We ordered the $65 pork and beef combination for 3 people and it was perfect. The quality and taste of the meats were excellent.  We loved the side dishes because it was a delicious variety.  Compared to Hobak which doesn't always cook your food, Magal which doesn't always cook your food, and Gen which has poor quality food, Goong is our favorite AYCE Korean BBQ in Vegas. No added charges at the end unless it's for drinks is the best part of the dining experience.

Since we only ordered one dish they cooked it in the kitchen. To cook it at your table you have to order 2 or more dishes.  Cooking it in the kitchen is the way to go. 6zNF5SOmmHHO0U89yZQcZA.text: Goong Korean BBQ - Las Vegas (2017 Yelp Review #250)  The southwest is blowing up big time.  Goong Korean BBQ is a great alternative to Chinatown's busy KBBQ joints.  The food at Goong KBBQ is fabulous and there's never a wait.  All meats are cooked by the staff (not you) and everything is awesome.  Their marinated sliced rib eye, prime brisket, and the Wagyu top sirloin ranks as my favorites.  If it's just me and Terri, we're almost always ordering the Beef Platter ($65 serves 2-3).  We recently dined here for dinner and because we had a pork lover with us, we got the Beef & Pork Platter ($85 serves 4-5).  The entire meal was awesome and a ton of ban chan also came with the meal.  Other highlights include their fish cakes, the seafood pancake, and of course, the steamed egg. The BBQ is not AYCE, but the servings of meat is generous enough to fill up your belly.

c1UBHzL_QWjUZzWeV_9Wiw.text: This is a what I would call a high-end Korean BBQ. First of all this is no an AYCE BBQplace, but what you loose in quantity, you make up for in quality. The quality of the meats and the side dishes is the best I've seen at a Korean BBQ. We ordered the beef platter for $65, which came with 6 different meats (prime rib eye, wagu top sirloin, prime chuck flat, prime flat iron, thinly slicked prime brisket, and marinated thinly slicked ribeye). The meats were fresh and extremely tender. They meats were served with about 20 different side dishes and rice. They also cook the meats for you, which was a first for me. I actually like that, but it might be against concept of Korean BBQ, where you have to cook your own meats. We also ordered peach soju, my fiance really enjoyed it. I'd say if you are out on a date night then I'd order. Your lady would love it. Overall this is the best Korean BBQ experience I've had in Vegas. It's little on the pricey side and its not AYCE, but it's quality make up for the cost.

9VwX_GYtiO1YwC4krx89JA.text: Take away: A place you'll share with friends.   1. Ambiance: I always start how a place makes me feel when I walk in and the first thing you'll notice is that it's beautiful. Rainbow Blvd has become Vegas' hotspot for Asian concepts and Goong has set a new bar. If you're from Vegas, you've come to accept the mini-mall as our neighborhood landscape. Used to be that when you have relatives or friends visit, you'd bring them to the Strip. Seriously, options have swung open. You can tell design is important to Goong--I'll take my wife to a date, co-workers for lunch, even client meetings and won't be embarrassed. It's buttoned up, these guys are good. Check out the details, there's a lot of great nuances from signage, photographs, sculptures, mirrors...  2. Food:  There were 4 adults with us, and ordered the Goong Special ($145) which had so much good stuff with 9 meat items and plethora of wholesome side dishes. We had smiles and waving white flags after the meal. It just tasted so fresh. If you're gonna just have one thing, get the PRIME SHORT RIB (wow). Take a walk down the middle of the restaurant, you'll see the butcher actually slicing the meats. The quality is unlike any other Korean place in Vegas--even have the meat displayed and labeled--very proud to show you how fresh the meat looks. On the display when I was there was Rib Eye, Top Sirloin, and Chuck Flat--all of them Wagyu.  3. Service:  Servers looked very smart with black unis. Just enough attention and polite when you ask them for things. One of my pet peeves is timing as in when plates need to be removed (hate having empty plates just meandering) and given this is a Korean restaurant with countless of plates on the table, they did a good job.   ----------------------------------------------  Listen up restauranteurs wanting to enter Rainbow Blvd--Goong should be your model as it challenges what a restaurant in "local" Vegas should be. You seriously can turn your place to something the community can be proud of and as Goong is in mine, they'll be seeing me a lot.

u4tKJQeHYP57Z5vOOg_fZQ.text: Las Vegas has seemingly always had buffets, and the norm for Korean BBQ has similarly been all you can eat. Fortunately, we now have multiple high-quality, non-AYCE KBBQ options including this one.  Goong Korean BBQ Restaurant is one of perhaps a triumvirate of (relatively) pricey, premium meat restaurants. Normally, I write about other businesses vaguely, but I'm going to refer to other restaurants by name, especially because I intend to draw some comparisons/contrasts with one of them in particular: Hobak. I have eaten there multiple times. I have not yet tried 8 Oz, the newest kid on the block. I have also eaten at Magal, which I consider to be a lower tier option and which i've only tried once, so I won't talk about them.  Perhaps the best part of the visit was how we were seated immediately at around 6:15pm on a Sunday night. Hobak always seems to have a long wait. The interior here is welcoming and feels more "traditional" in a way than that faux-street feel at Hobak. I also like the lantern-esque light covers with red and blue colors seemingly lifted straight from South Korea's flag. I'm told that those represent the ancient balancing forces of yin and yang.  Anyway, let's move on to the food. Rather than order a la carte, my two friends and I split a Marinated Meat Combination Platter ($65). We could've gone pricier, but we had a feeling that this would satiate our appetites, and it did. The meats did indeed all come marinated, but none of them tasted cheap - except perhaps the chicken, but nobody goes to KBBQ to eat chicken, right? Prime boneless short rib was highly marbled and easily tasted the best, but the thinly sliced rib eye, pork ribs, and pork outside skirt were delicious as well. Oh, and an employee cooked all of those for us. One difference from Hobak: no charcoal for added smoky flavor. Fortunately, I didn't miss that so much.  The combo comes with a steamed egg bowl and a choice of soup (one bowl). The steamed egg was as fluffy as hoped and was ideally salted. Our choice of soup was soft tofu (aka soondubu) and our protein choice for that was seafood. I can't remember tasting a cleaner broth in this type of soup before, which let the seafood flavors come out and play. The calamari was al dente but easily chewed apart, and the shrimp was cooked properly too. The tofu was soft. Surprisingly, this was my favorite soondubu in memory.  Side dishes were good if not great. I won't go all of through the banchan in detail because they were so numerous, but they all tasted fresh - y'know, crunchy when it was supposed to be and all that jazz. Seafood cakes (warmed on the grill) were quite good. The pink pickled daikon was surprisingly sweet. The japchae was great. The creamy dressing on the individual salads was not as heavy as anticipated.  Complimentary "dessert" was a cool (temperature-wise) bowl of cinnamon tea. It had some balanced sweetness and tasted like cinnamon, and it was surprisingly refreshing. (They do have options for ice cream and such if you're in the mood.)  Despite my initial concerns about cost, I'm glad that I finally heeded Desyree's advice (yes, that Desyree) and visited Goong. It impressed me with service, flavors, and relative affordability. I can't really pick a favorite between this and Hobak just yet, so if you haven't tried either of them, then try both.

1cbThVc0ZNejVhGNVjUQfg.text: One of my favourite things about this place is the generosity and variety of little dishes that swiftly arrive at the table right after you place the order. They change them up a bit from week to week (so you'll never get bored) but they keep the crowd pleasers like japchae (glass noodles with aromatics and vegetables), pickled radishes, kimchi (a tad crispy, with perfect balance of spices), banchan (blanched spinach with a touch of garlic, soy sauce and sesame oil). So every time there's a room for delight and surprise yet your favs are all there as well. And ofcause, you can ask for a re-fill of the dish you just can't get enough of)   The meats (pork belly, wagyu beef, rib eye, spicy chicken) are always marinated to perfection, so I would highly recommend to order them. The bigger the group of people you are with, the better, as you will be able to try more kinds of dishes.   We usually visit Goong for lunch, so parking or lack of tables is never an issue.   Prices are great, service is swift, selection of music is sometimes quite unusual, but who cared when the food is yummy, at least I don't.

T4ToGh6OANdp8V3M-hfNMw.text: We came here around 1pm in search for some great Korean BBQ and we found it.  This is a MUST TRY if you are in the area.  Decor and ambiance is amazing.  You have the option of the common tables with grills, floor seats where you have to off your shoes, and a separate area for larger groups.  In terms of the service, they were very friendly, knowledgeable and attentive to our needs.  We were greeted and seated immediately upon entering.    Menu has a wide variety of options.  Lunch was available (until 4pm) when we came in but we wanted to try one of the platters.  We ordered the beef platter and terms of the quantity it was more than enough for 3 people.  My favorite cuts were prime rib eye and marinated rib eye.  It also came with tons of sides which probably were the best I have ever had.   Parking might be an issue especially on a weekend because of the amount of spaces and restaurants located in the vicinity.  But if you go early I doubt it would be a problem.   Overall the service, food, and ambiance is excellent!  Can't wait to come back and try everything else on the menu.

IboA02WOI8ajaWzKrmPyGA.text: I definitely like the atmosphere, it's very clean and open- lists of vents around the restaurant and even a fan blowing. The service is pretty decent the servers attend to your table, when ever possible. Upon arrival we were seated accordingly, but it seemed in an area where the server had to many tables to handle, but he did try his best. Luckily someone stepped in to help out.  Now on to the food- they are very generous on the sides. Although it was missing a few of my favorites, they did have some new ones to try.  Now onto the important part, the meat! Now this is why I gave my 3 stars, the portions were very small, we ordered the beef combo- that was suppose to be for 2-3 It was more like 2 people, the brisket was so skimpy that I had to ask is that suppose to be for two? The guy assured me it was 8oz, I was thrown back with 8oz?  Maybe I am so use to other bbq spots being more generous on portions. The actual restaurant called 8ounce literally has more and that place is portioned at 8ounce.  I was a little upset, since this is my favorite dish to eat. All in all the service and sides would not make me come back- the set price for the combination is over priced and I'm leaving this place still hungry. My other minus of a star is that my kid was not acknowledged properly.  No dessert for him, as the adults get to drink cinnamon tea while he watches. The server didn't even want to give him a placemat It's the little things that count for a kid friendly establishment  I just feel that they don't accommodate much on their dining experience  Overall if you want a lunch portion for dinner, then this is your place.

ngy-EXH8KSi40kM61AmN8Q.text: I've been going here for a while, so it's time to write a review.... First, this is not a review of Korean BBQ. If you don't know what Korean BBQ is, I refer you to koreanbbq.com or something. I'm torn about writing a review - because I really like this place, and I can always get a seat. On the one hand, I don't want it to get too crowded; but I also don't want it to go under for lack of business. So the best thing you can do if my review persuades you, is to go, but go when I'm not there. Like for breakfast, or after 1 am. This is not All-You-Can-Eat-Then-Feel-Disgusted-But-Rationalize-By-Telling-Yourself-You-Saved-Money. For that, go to Tofu Hut on Spring Mountain. Going is spacious, always sweater-weather cool, quiet, and generally pleasant. We always get the meat special, and add an order of beef tongue and marinated bulgogi. The quality of the meat is superb. Banchan: it's banchan heaven. Great choices, always slightly different, with frequent refills if you want. The only thing is the conventional salad is just that - very conventional. That's made up by the other choices, particularly the rice noodles and kimchee. Service is great. They always seem to remember us and our preferences without being creepy or judgemental (Olive Garden, looking at you with your "oh, having the AYCE salad, pasta, and breadsticks AGAIN! aren't you"). They'll help you burn your meat if you want, or let you make carbon all by yourself.

yFm4GWpNRi5sFIA_14WjOg.text: I don't mind waiting but when even if it's for 30mins , but when people who came after we did gets severed before we do, I wonder what's going on inside there heads? But I'll go on, while we were waiting I could clearly see 4-5 tables opened. So why were we waiting ?  Why didn't the host or manager inform us why we weren't being seated like its normal to have customers waiting? The food was good but they need to do a better job at customer service.  The server brought us a soup , we assumed that the soup came with what we ordered, but then the server told the soup back after we already eat out of it, hopefully they didn't give it to another table because that would be gross.

Gg1fY3E9mCXYejjatf2QIg.text: If I can give them 100 stars, I would! I believe Goong means royalty or kings so you basically eat and served like royalty here. The food is 11 out of 10!!! We ordered the beef platter and all the meat was so juicy and flavorful. Their quality beats all of the other kbbq place I've tried. I've never had so many banchan besides here. EXCEPT there is this one Korean male worker in his about late twenties who gave us attitude when we wanted to use a different grill instead of the black grill because we wanted the meat to taste better. -FCcUz7NeQmhq2OuvIaVIA.text: The only thing this place had going was they would cook your food for you....NOPE NOT ANYMORE!!  My family of 6 came in for lunch and ordered 5 orders of brisket, 2 bulgogi, 2 marinated short rib and 6 bowls of rice along with a few sodas.  **BTW The portions for happy hour are reduced!!!  Which equals out to the same price for regular portion BTW**  The reason why we enjoy coming here normally is because they cook for you. Or at least do some or most of the cooking but that's not the case anymore. They don't care about you at all! You have to flag them down constantly.  I understand for all you can eat Korean bbq they do not cook for you. But this establishment is NOT all you can eat. Plus they were not busy!! This place is NEVER busy compared to the rest of the Korean bbq places in the vicinity.  So I don't understand why they would stop cooking or assisting you in the cooking.  Plus now they've significantly reduced the amount of side dishes that they used to put out. No more onion salad. No more beans. No more different kinds of pickled radishes. The salad they do put out is such a tiny amount that a single person can literally pick it up and place on their plate and it's done. So you have to flag them down again and request more salad. I honestly don't see this place lasting for much longer. It's been a good ride tho but I do not recommend this place to my colleagues anymore. I just recommend them to the all you can eat places down the street since the service is the same if not better.

cqotTMCZq8caH6-dxm2wcQ.text: My boyfriend, son, and I decided to give this place a try since we love Korean BBQ and it was in the same shopping center as SOYO and Oyshi. We just so happen to frequent SOYO and Oyshi so why not try the awesome looking Goong restaurant as well, right?  Well, we were not disappointed! The food was amazing. We ordered two orders of Galbi, Wagyu plate, and their bulgolgi fried rice! The quality of the meat was very impressive and pricing was quite fair.  The atmosphere of this restaurant is really laid back. They have sections where you actually remove your shoes to eat. Super cute, but we were seated on the side instead. We also weren't in the mood to cook our own meals so we asked if they could prepare it for us in the kitchen instead. They did so without hesitation which I thought was kinda cool.  I also gave their white peach martini a try and had my boyfriend order their apple martini, which I really enjoyed because it was sweet and not very strong. They weren't in martini glasses so I found that kind of odd, but still good nonetheless.  I highly recommend this place!

TJNZ03U-br_bSWS79JV9wA.text: Very nice decor and tables (fancy for Korean restaurant). Large venue.   Food is high quality and delicious. Service was fine but not as attentive to what I'm used to. Missed some items, slow to cook the meat. Maybe that's how Vegas does things. But no significant complaints. cOLE0m_oZYVmp_8tN2clPw.text: First time here! Literally typing this review in while having a server cook me KBBQ. :D They start off with a plethora of side dishes - the usual kimchi, radish, two different salads, japchae, potato salad etc. You can choose to sit at a booth or the traditional style tables where you sit down on a pillow with no shoes on. They use 2 different grills depending in how the meat is seasoned. Definitely like the array of quality meats they have here - I ordered the Beef & Pork Platter - and I'm in love with their brisket! I am usually not impressed with pork belly in most kbbq places, but Goong surprisingly had theirs rather juicy and moist without seasoning. Service is definitely on point, most of the servers were generally male and cooked all the meat in a prompt and proper fashion. It was a nice touch having green tea salt as one of the seasonings, I really liked that as I am a fan of anything green tea lol. My friend also noticed that they were playing instrumentals from the Spirited Away soundtrack in the background, which really made my night as it gave a nice bonus to the neutral but grounded ambiance they had at Goong. :) Will definitely come again with friends and family! They'll be serving ice cream next week so for those with a sweet tooth check it out!

SDjhfzddswJtkLgZ9829aQ.text: This place is excellent. Great place to take a crew for a lunch meeting. There were 4 of us,  had the beef and pork platter and honestly there was more food than we could eat. Excellent service. I'll definitely be back. Everything tasted great.

BRFVilAYHH79Ji_2sDV7SA.text: The best quality of red meat! I love it here and I will be back and bring some friends and family here. I love everything there! You guys are the best! Thank you for great food and service.

B03ymTYkk5kQhv0vaFloZQ.text: It tastes really great! The beef is so juicy and tender, the marinated meats tastes awesome as well.

qu2hmxpIO8AYhdTpTJ_6hA.text: Been here several times.  Consistent high quality meats . Clean and modern decor with excellent services.

QMGDwI7ZH0ywzZ-C5kWZlw.text: Decided to come here for dinner and arrived around 7pm and we got seated immediately. There was a choice between sitting at a booth or korean style seating. We decided to go with the Korean style where you have to take off your shoes and sit on a large blue pillow.  1. Food: Decided to go with the prime rib eye, beef tongue, and thinly sliced brisket - all of which was delicious. The way the meat is presented has to be the best I've seen in a Korean BBQ place. Banchan (side dishes) consisted of 14 dishes. Instead of water, they provide barley tea - loved it! The meat can be small in portions and on the expensive side, however the quality is makes up for it. In the middle of the restaurant there's even a little window where you can see the butchers cut and plate the meat.  2. Service: Everyone had all black uniforms, which makes the place look professional - then I noticed they were wearing croc style shoes which I thought were no bueno. LOL  The servers were very attentive and always checked up on us. They even cook the food for you, but sometimes I would prefer to cook it myself. They were very polite and got whatever I asked for in a timely manner. Every plate of banchan was explained to us, and they also asked which meat we wanted to eat next.   3. Ambiance: The decor in there is very charming. There are sculptures, golden masks on the wall, photographs, and mirrors. There are a lot of little details around the restaurant that shows they care about appearance. The music in there wasn't too loud or too quiet, but we weren't able to hear it once more people started coming in.  I feel that you get what you pay for at this place - although the bill can end up being expensive, so be careful of what you order and the prices!

JVgzknW5Z4qr8fCGattp4Q.text: Everything was very good, and service was amazing. The only thing I though was just "ok" was some of the sides, such as the sweet mashed potato that was pretty tasteless. Other than that meats were excellent. I do recommend.

viWZd9u3WcbqI_BkLQGDRw.text: Totally on point 5 star Korean Bbq place. The side dishes are great and the staff are really friendly and helped us cook our foods on the grill. We were served a nice and cold tea which was surprisingly good and unexpected as I always like hot tea to go with my food but no complaint here since the cold tea was nice and refreshing.

U9QXmT-LeEQWR_mlQThfVQ.text: I have been to this restaurant 4 times. The first time I was so impressed I couldn't wait to return. They changed the type of grill depending on the fat content of the beef.  They also "introduced " the various cuts of meat.  Like many restaurants, it seems like once they get established when they are new, the quality and service start to wane.  My most recent visit was last week.  The server was rushed, the grill was never changed, and the quality of the food was average. My family and I will not be returning.  It actually saddens me.  I am a big fan of Korean BBQ, and I thought I had found a good quality restaurant close to my house.

0ooDG7XBntgo5Yw6wey3cA.text: Great Korean bbq spot . The restaurant was very clean. The service was great . There were 3 of us and we went at the end of a night on a Sunday so they close earlier on Sunday's . The service was still great even though we were the last people in the restaurant . We got the beef and pork platter. The beef was top notch quality and was mouth watering good . The pork was great too . All of the sides were good . The pickled radish being my favorite . Everything about this place is great and it's a great value too . The 3 of us were plenty full and satisfied and for only 120 all in with gratuity . I will be back soon.

iclKgSBBoey-s0eM43bkQQ.text: First time here and love it. Food is super fresh, delicious and high quality comparing to most other Korean BBQ place. The service was great. Jihoon and another server were very attentive. We'll definitely be back.

oE-X7PK00sl7mPUTl5VvXQ.text: This is one of the few Korean BBQ located outside china town. The decor and atmosphere are very modern and sophisticated. When you enter the restaurant they give you the option to sit in a normal booth or in their traditional tables where you have to take your shoes off and dine on the floor. Their menu is pretty extensive. However, they have preset menus that can feed 4-6 people. I think the preset menus were the best options as you get a pretty good variety of meats. We ordered the Goong special which includes wagyu rib eye, wagyu sirloin, prime short ribs, wagyu chuck flat, marinated prime short ribs, black tiger shrimp and a lot of Korean sides. The quality of the meat is evident. The taste of the wagyu meat was very good. I especially liked the rib eye and the marinated prime short ribs. The service was just ok, the service was kind of slow and not very efficient. Also we had to be constantly asking to refill our side dishes as they were never offered to us. Overall, a good restaurant if you wanna have good quality meat and a great atmosphere.

cFUhOF3318i8o5yYO4d3tQ.text: I'm a little nervous about this place becoming too popular, but this is truly the best Korean BBQ in Vegas. They bring out the most side dishes and the highest quality of meat. Everyone I know ends up coming here multiple times per week.

ya1vOjetU_97JueZ5fme8A.text: This place is one of my favorite korean BBQ spots. The quality of the meat and banchan is great! It's reasonably priced, casual, and the service is good. I would definitely recommend this place even for a good korean BBQ quick fix.

Jxim0KtJqop3nqPwlaXtnw.text: This review is for 3.5 stars.   As far as taste of the food, Goong is as good as it gets in Vegas. Some of he most extensive banchan in the game with soups per person and about a dozen small plates including a few radishes and a few kimchi offerings.  Though they charge extra for refills, as an FYI. We had the marinated meat platter ($65) which included 2 porks, 2 beers and a chicken. Couple that with about 5 sojus and the meal was tasty. However, on a Saturday night it was unbelievably dead. With that said, our servers had nothing to do yet we're still a little angry with us as we were eating a little slow to their taste and it was ruin the cooking preparation.  And we got last call way too early and were rushed out. Finally, they offer free ice cream with a Yelp review, but they stand over your shoulder as you write it which artificially inflates the review.  Overall a good Korean BBQ but not the best, or cheapest, by any means in the city.

iH-5s6syqeKvO7miTMHI1A.text: I've gotten much larger servings at other Korean Bbq restaurants for similarly priced menu items. We ordered just the marinated, thinly sliced ribeye and galbi shortrib entrees, and even my elderly mom (who doesn't each much) complained that it was barely enough to satisfy her hunger. The $20 galbi (1 bone and some small chunks) was a little tough to chew, and the $13 ribeye bulgogi tasted a little too salty. The service was also slower than expected, and we had to quiet our grumbling stomachs with the banchan dishes because it took almost 30 minutes for the kitchen to make our 2 simple meat orders! We sat on the booth side because we didn't feel like doing the table cooking, but on hindsight, we probably could've had our meals ready sooner if we had cooked it ourselves. Neither the food nor the service was worth the total on the bill.  I only went there for lunch, and I'm wondering if the better quality meats are being saved for dinner. Too bad I'm not interested in trying this place again.
