EEH_fZjNHB_gHc36a06Quw.text: Wow! This is by far the best Korean bbq I've ever been to. It's very nice inside with a floor pillow seating, table seating and private rooms. The cold barley tea wasn't for me but the table next to us wondered where they could buy it. We ordered the beef platter $65 which is 6 courses of beef and we added the shrimp $12-15. Everything was amazing, even the many side dishes. Kimchi fried rice was spicy but a delicious platter.   4 stars due to the service. We arrived at opening, 11:30 with a reservation. It was our first time in and we were the second family through the door. We weren't offered any menu suggestions or even drinks. I finally had to stand to get attention to order. My husband insisted we leave like another table had as it had been 20 minutes with still no service. I counted 8 tables, most with the same issue. As the huge family of 6 left the only server on the floor stared the family down. Quite rude and unprofessional in my opinion.   We will be back but we do highly suggest that if your charging good money (our bill was $97 before tip) you don't cheapen the experience with no staff. The entire two hours we were there we received no refills and asked for extra side dishes that never came. Two tables for this environment should receive one server. Two people for the entire place is ridiculous.

WiJnTmylYvUEHH6OgJrLew.text: Tried it on a whim and it was great! Gihon was so awesome and took such great care of us. It seemed pricey but food was plentiful and we left satisfied and full.  Had chicken bulgogi and tiger prawns and it was perfect for 2. Can't wait to come back!

5budcrRML5aKXIpV1psq9A.text: Goong stands out pretty well in quality terms of Korean bbq.   The wagyu is extremely juicy and flavorful and doesn't even require any seasoning to be enjoyed. The side dishes were also abundant, including steamed egg, spicy tofu soup, 2 salads and more.   Service is very well considering.. It's a Korean establishment (it's okay to say, I'm Korean) and tops off other places cough tofu hut cough. We ordered the beef and pork platter and it came with enough food to more than satisfy 3 people. They will have ice cream as a dessert option in the near future which we were able to sample with our review. It actually has a surprisingly fresh and rich French vanilla taste and has good creamy consistency for a house made dessert, I was impressed.  The wagyu and bulgogi was the most tender imo off the meat selection, and being able to get a larger platter to try a variety of selections makes the experience more fun and enjoyable; something I highly recommend.  I have to say this place was moderately priced and pretty good in terms of quality and service.. Deserving my 4 star recommendation. Kahhhmn sahhmnii dahh

IE0YowX3jhEmZs0Jt4aRiw.text: I really like this place.  The portions are not super large, but definitely adequate.    Service was fast.  We ordered a group meal (beef) and it was very reasonable and enough for all.   Overall, it's a great place for Korean, with great staff and service.

EezXgYPKJ21s-G8cIv0w7w.text: Restaurants all over the place throw around the words "wagyu" and "Kobe" these days and it confuses consumers.  It gives the False idea that some rural farmer in Japan prepared this majestic, gently massaged, beer-fed cow specifically for their plate.  Because of the lack of uniform rules on beef labeling, this happens regularly with zero repercussions to them.  They can say anything they want!  You think video poker bars in Vegas really have authentic wagyu beef in the form of sliders ready to be served at 2am for $10?  It's a name that catches the eye and allows them to charge more.  Just like "super white tuna".    American tastes have come a long way from when lean meats were king.  They currently take a backseat to pork belly, the "more white than red" beef and even chicken thigh.  I didn't ask about the origins of Goong's product, or if they had any concrete proof that it was truly wagyu, but their quality is clearly a step above the standard Vegas KBBQ and that makes it worth going to in my book.    To shorten time perusing the menu for our party of 5, the Goong special at $145 was the easiest way to sample it all.  This included a nice selection from pork jowl to prime flat iron to wagyu top sirloin.  The ribeye and short rib were my personal favorites and met all my criteria for great grilled beef, which is FJT (fatty, juicy, tender).  I enjoy a little blood, so no piece stayed on the grill for long.  I am normally not very sensitive about service (perhaps all those Chinese restaurants I went to growing up dulled my senses), but the rushed, stop-go service left something to be desired.  I'd prefer the servers either put the meat on the grill and see it through to its completion, or leave us alone to do it all.  There was one point where a gentleman placed a nice looking piece over the fire, asked my friend if she liked her beef cooked "medium", she responded "yes" and then he proceeded to walk away from the table!  What did that mean? Was he coming back to flip it or leaving that up to us?  Should we just put more on the grill when we're done?  They make such an effort to present the meat so royally with the thick, uniform, labeled cuts in a classy and quiet dining atmosphere; it's a shame that this was the problem.  They were also more reactive than proactive when it came to refilling banchan as we always had to ask about getting something instead of them noticing the empty bowl and asking if we wanted more.  That's all fixable though.        Constantly losing track of which cuts were being eaten, which I blame on attempting to be social (ha), made some of the meat feel a little less special.  "Wait.  What cut is this again?" was said numerous times.  Maybe I need flashing lights that say the name of the meat.  Regardless, I'll be back here to satisfy my fix of good marbled beef. 3.6511111 stars.

NMtJjVgFyrxUV65q8GAfbg.text: Let's see high reviews again and I jump on any new Korean restaurant so of course I had to come here. After having really good Korean food in LA I promised to never eat Korean in Vegas so I don't get disappointed. But this place has pretty good quality in comparison to other Korean restaurants in Vegas.   First of all my hubby and I came here and we're the only customers. Later 3 tables got filled up but service was pretty good at first.   Ok who goes to Korean BBQ for the salad? But really I appreciate a good salad with my food. They brought us two salads. One is excellent and I got many refills. One I didn't touch which had bottled dressing that I did not care for. It was more of an American salad look to it. I liked the variety in the banchan and overall it seemed fresh. I didn't particularly like the little patties, potato salad was good but I try to avoid carbs and stick to salad. Japchae was good.  I found the carrot sticks and I think it was cucumber with red pepper sauce odd (their take on buffalo wings' carrots and celery with ranch?)  On to the meat. We got the combo which it said is for 3 people. It didn't have all the meats I wanted to try but we figured since it's our first time we will try the combo. The majority of the meats were good,not amazing but the portion did seem small of how much of each they give. It ended up filling us up so it was fine. I thought the way the meat was served was cute and in theory sounded good but it didn't end up working too well then labels were removed and they put more than one meat on the grill (some were the same size) and so it was hard to differentiate between the meats and I had to ask waiters a few times which meat was what.   I like the high ceilings, the non existent smoke filled rooms that usually KBBQ has, the modern look. It definitely sparked my interest enough to return and order a la carte next time.   Although it does not compare to LA I think it's pretty good for Vegas. I want to try it again before making my final verdict.  I did have a little issue which is the same at all Korean restaurants- do I cook or does the waiter? They start off cooking then it's me then it's me waiting "Are they coming back? Do we just do it ourselves?" are questions commonly asked. I don't want to offend them but I don't want my meat overcooked!

drKDKEaMSx-6Y3rbtv3gUQ.text: I cannot stop thinking about this place. And I also don't know why I haven't yelped this place either!  I don't know where to begin. I don't know what to say. Except... I pray your business does very well, food quality and service does not decline but remains consistent and amazing.   My husband and I have gone here for date night several times and we just love it. The service, quality of meats and the delicious ban chan are all superb.  I brought my daughter and niece here to celebrate my niece's 16th birthday. They love KPop, BTS and what ever band now days so there were very excited. I grew up eating Korean food so anytime I get a chance to eat it, I'm there. I ordered the set menu for 3 - 4 and also ordered the marinated samgyeopsal. I am so proud and impressed with my girls - we demolished every thing in front of our faces. The japchae, salad, kimchi, radish are all my favorite ban chan.  Living in Henderson, this place is awesome. I don't have to go to Chinatown for bomb Korean food.

zZ6gEEyXGNhFaNopjQuI-w.text: I love Korean food and have been to Korea many times. This is a plus and minus when trying out Korean restaurants. Do you critic the food as being authentic or as being just great food? Thus why I am torn.  The decor is fresh and modern but due to the design of the restaurant it feels claustrophobic. The wall next to our table did not allow us to see around the restaurant. The seat did not allow you to sit close to the table or to the back of the booth.  The menu was difficult at best. Most of it was in Hungul and the lettering was very small. Due to the dark lighting and small print, we had to forgo the menu and ask questions of the server.   The waitress was pretty new and needed to ask others about the menu. She also was having difficulty with the table grill.   We decided on being safe and order Bulgogi. Typically a Korean meal is served with a stainless bowl filled with rice, and 8-12 "side dishes". This meal was served with four (4) small side dishes; Kimchee, glass noodles, fish cakes, and potato salad.  The Bulgogi was cooked at the table - by the server - and was average in grade of meat and flavor.   As we're new to the area and are looking to make up our new "Go To" list of restaurants, we will be continuing our quest. This did not make the list for us.

LF0sDeLLUFL8iKK95LMj-Q.text: Excellent food, amazing presentation, the staff is nice and will cook the food for you.  The decor looks well kept and modern.  I ordered the beef platter and really liked it. Next time I will try the Wagyu.

kN-10hvbjVQExNuB0XR_hg.text: This might just be my new favorite Korean bbq spot in town. The space is divided into a traditional and non-traditional area. I recommend dining in the traditional area, but you might want to skip out on this if you need back support or have stinky feet (although the bbq will most likely take care of that smell).  Their menu is not AYCE, but the meat and banchan quality definitely reflect on the money that you pay. In the end, the price difference isn't too large for better quality food IMO. It looks like they have a number of lunch combos and combo platters for 2-3 people for $65. We ended up going for the beef & pork platter for $85 meant for 4-5 people, but splitting amongst 3 guys. It was well worth it.  First, I have to acknowledge that this place has one of the best banchan offerings I've had. We got all of my favorites including one steamed egg, soft tofu stew, and a cold kimchi soup to share. We also got fish cake, japchae, kimchi, pickled radish for wraps, kimchi radish, unlimited dollar coin-sized pancakes, mashed potatoes, greens, green salad, onion salad, and one large pancake to share.  The progression of meats starts with light and becomes heavier in flavor as the dinner goes on. They do all the cooking while you sit back and eat. We started with the prime brisket, prime ribeye, wagyu top sirloin, prime chuck flat, wagyu short plate, pork belly, to finally the bulgogi, and the spicy marinated pork. We finished dinner with a cold cinnamon drink, which was nice.   Service was very fast and attentive. Will definitely be back for some more!

iuGQRQoEoB4gP095TQZE8w.text: Definitely one of the best spots for modern korean bbq in town. Quality of the prime beef cuts and the pork are outrageously good and absolutely delicious. They have two sets of tables where you can sit traditionally without shoes, and tables at regular height for dining.   I absolutely love the combos they have here for the meat plates because of the variation. There are a lot of side dishes (banchan) to eat alongside all the primary dishes/entrees.   The seafood options are unique from other places in town for kbbq and everything here feels, tastes, and looks fresh to order. I love the overall experience when I am here because service standards and food quality standards all check out.   Thank you Goong team for a wonderful dining experience time after time!

0SOG9IqxvJ-hMqHK09420A.text: Quite the different experience from your average KBBQ joint, with quality meat and unsurprisingly, matching quality cost. A couple of defining characteristics: floor seats (kind of like enclosed floor booths), they cook the meat for you as opposed to you cooking the meat yourself, none of the meat is frozen. We were a group of 6 and we decided on the premium bundle instead of choosing a la carte, and had many cuts of well marbled non-marinated meat. That along with the banchan served and complimentary cinnamon tea (good for digestion perhaps?), we left perfectly full for about $165 which was truly reasonable!

CPMYM_TjFlChMvYrfQp76w.text: Even if you aren't into this kind of food its the beez neez!    I am by no means into Azn cuisine... just never been a fan but this experience was pretty awesome.  I had my doubts because the waiter brought out some food that I don't consider normal and then came the rib eye, steak, chicken, etc.   If this is your first time doing KBBQ let the waiter know and they will cook/turn the meat for you, and they are cool with you asking questions.  I asked him "What's that" like 10+ times.  If you aren't a n00b like me, you can cook your food over the grill.  My buddy ordered the meat platter, and everything turned out to be excellent.  The marinated meat to some of the sides, and the ambiance.  The parking in the lot is hectic for some reason so you might have to park a little ways from the entrance.   I don't usually try new stuff because I'm stubborn, but I'm glad I did.  This place was a good first experience, and I look forward to coming back.

VNiqGLADTjxhnuG9LGfN6g.text: Came here last night for my brother's graduation party and it started out pretty rough but rebounded quickly.  We had reservations for 8 at 4 and when we arrived they told us we didn't.  They eventually found our reservation (for two sets of 4, since each table seats 4) and we got in, 10 minutes later.  We had 6 menus between us and when my father asked for more, the waitress took my sisters and gave it to him...but then I asked for two more and two were brought out.    We ordered our food, the two biggest things on the menu and the appetizers started coming out and filling our table which is cool because of the variety but the lack of space on the table was annoying.  As she was bringing out the side dishes, she spilled some sauce all over my brother's shoe and then just left it there until like 15 minutes later she got a napkin and put it on the floor over the spill (never picking it up over the course of the whole meal).  She then offered to clean my brother's shoe, again after about 20 minutes.  She took it and cleaned it which was nice but didn't do the best of jobs.  My sister also never got her apple soju she ordered.  I also feel like pop should have free refills instead of $2/can.    Now, on to the food.  The side dishes were plentiful and some of them were indeed good but there was also a fair amount that were just ehh but I blame that on my lack of knowledge of Korean food and how little I've had of it.  The meat started coming out and it looked incredible.  Marbling was perfect, size was plentiful, and unlike some Korean BBQ places, the waitresses at Goong cook your food at your table for you so there's no guessing on when it is done.  The meats were amazing and just about erased my doubts about this place from the service.  They were spectacularly tender and melted in your mouth.  I loved the green salt that we had to add to it!   There was so much that our other table couldn't finish their food so the chefs cooked it up and packaged it to go for them which was awesome.  Even though the service started off pretty shaky, the quality of the ingredients and the fact that we didn't have to cook on a crappy, under-powered plate really brought this place miles ahead of other places in the valley (cough cough Gen).  I would gladly go back here because it was so darn tasty!  Maybe the service was ehh because we had a big group or because they only had one person sserving us even though the restaurant was dead or because she was just having an off day...idk but regardless, if you want some quality Korean BBQ, come here!

The only problem was that the servers would repeatedly say they'd do something and then not do it, like take our water thing for a refill and then never refill it or never bring a fork for our chopstick-impaired diner. I just walked to the back and asked for it eventually because he legit has no clue how to use chopsticks, so his food was overcooking. No one seemed mad at me for doing this, but it made me feel like I was being disrespectful when I was just trying to get our water back/a fork.   However, as long as they're fine with me walking to the back counter, I'm down to come back. I hope they hire on maybe one more person so there can be an extra set of hands to make sure the tables are attended to. I also hope they get enough diners that they can afford an extra person because it's definitely a worthwhile spot in the southwest.

VXjQmiifllU-92dP9WoVIQ.text: My mother and I checked this place out based on a friend's recommendation, and they did not disappoint! We were used to going to All You Can Eat KBBQ places, but this definitely was a grade above those other types of places.   When you first walk-in, the ambience is beautiful! There is a combination of tables where you take off your shoes to sit down or regular seating. Everything was very clean.  My mother and I ordered the Beef Plater Combination (good for 2-3 people) which consisted of Prime Rib Eye, Wagyu Top Sirloin, Prime Chuck Flat, Prime Flat Iron, Thinly Sliced Prime Brisket, and Marinated Thinly Sliced Ribeye (bulgogi). This platter also came with a steamed egg and your choice of soup. The platter also came with a LOAD of sides, you can probably get full of them, but we paced ourselves to ensure we would be able to try everything.   Needless to say, everything was delicious! The quality of the meats were great! We ate our meal by each type of meat in order to appreciate each type of meat. Halfway through the meal, the grill was changed to cook the brisket and ribeye.   The staff top to bottom was great! There was always a different staff member serving our food, offering to cut or grill the meats, or accommodating any of our other requests. There was no one that gave us a bad experience.   There are many other dishes that give us lots of reason to come back, and my mom and I certainly will!

WZAtajYjEANOY3wgr6VPRg.text: My new favorite Korean restaurant. In the midst of these AYCE kbbqs this restaurant really stands out. The service was perfect.. Attentive but not intrusive.. They cook for you so you can really enjoy your meal. The meat quality is just so much better than the AYCE places and the side dishes or ( banchan) were delicious authentic and plentiful. First time we got the beef set for the three of us ( it's recommended for 2-3 people but the portion is quite large. There was a variety of meats including prime ribeye and filet mignon. Also included was a choice of soup .. Kimchi, bean paste or soft tofu. I've tried them all and all are delicious. You also get a steamed egg. I like how you don't have to stuff yourself because you can take home leftovers ( unlike AYCE ) I tend to totally overeat at those establishments thinking I have to get my money's worth. The food and service made my experiences here so much more enjoyable. Hope they keep up the quality. I will be a regular here I'm sure.

zpbvA8r9Ab_4LwEqXwPNgg.text: I am updating my review as I made reservations for a party of 13 (private room) three weeks ago and confirmed my reservation the day of my son's graduation. When I arrived with my party of 13, there were no tables available as they made way for  a party of 60 (for a one year old's birthday party) that was made only 1 week in advance.  They could have called me to cancel or tried to find a way to accommodate both parties; instead, they abruptly cancelled my reservation and made my celebration a complete bust.  We had to take our party to a restaurant next door.  This rudeness and greediness  is why I won't go back there again.  They did NOTHING TO MAKE UP FOR THEIR CANCELLATION.  Completely rude and unable to communicate in English.  Don't go there with any large party; they can't service the group.

O5zKp-bX0J1h2-RLHwL58A.text: With all these new Korean BBQ joints that's been popping up all over Las Vegas, i've been on a Kbbq quest to find the best tasting KBBQ in town!  This place is convenient and opens late. But the portions are extra small! My party (4ppl) got the beef combo platter($65). The platter included ALOT, ALOT of sides, from tofu soup, steamed egg, jap chae, kimchi, water kimchi....etc. That was a great plus to our dinner! I honestly could of just been satisfied with eating all the side dishes! When we started grilling our meat. The grill was not set high enough to sear the outside of the meat, instead it started dehydrating our meat! So our first & seconds sets of beef were extra dry! Tasted like beef jerky!! By the time we had the 3rd set of beef on the grill we finally turned up our grill ourselves. After all that I would say their beef is just okay. I personally would of liked my beef marinaded and or seasoned. We also ordered the grilled tiger prawns, it was ok.  The best tasting item here is probably the free jap Chae. Other than that I don't think I would be back! I'll rather drive the extra few miles down to spring mountain and eat at Hobak! I can't wait to try Magal BBQ soon!

Thank goodness the food was good and that is why it's deterring me from giving it less stars. Beef tongue was amazing. Super tender. Marinated kalbi was pretty good as well, definitely on the fattier side though. Sirloin steak was very good! Make sure you cook it medium rare though. I wasn't too impressed with the pork jowl. Although it was tender and juicy, it was too thin and had too much fat on it. I prefer hobak's pork jowl. Loved how much banchan they had. Mul nengmyeon was a bigg portion. I liked how it stayed cold for so long. I would come back for it again. This place can definitely accommodate big and also private parties as well. Great place to come eat with friends and family.

arXg8-z_LBfZ55CDGXjF-w.text: First Impression: I've been waiting for this place to open after driving by its fancy exterior signage many times. With all the KBBQ restaurants in town, this one definitely stole the spotlight. I finally got the chance to try this place and upon entering, I was fascinated by their interior design from the layout to the decorations of sculptures, mirrored vents, high ceiling and etc. My friend and I came here for dinner around 7pm and there were a plenty of seating available. We had the option of sitting at a booth OR, the traditional Korean seating where you take off your shoes and sit on these large blue pillows. Of course we went with the traditional way to get the full experience!  Food: We weren't super hungry so we decided to order a la carte but they do have party platters recommended for the size of your group. We ordered the prime rib eye, beef tongue (x3) and thinly sliced brisket (x2). They serve 14 banchans (side dishes) naming each one as its being served and barley tea instead of water that is light with a hint of roasty flavor. I would drink this over water any day because it's so refreshing! Your dipping choices are green tea salt (my favorite out of the 3 and super delicious paired with meat), regular salt with pepper and a dark sauce. Some of the meat is served on a black slate which adds a unique touch. The meat portion is quite small and the price is on the pricier side but seeing the quality, color and cut of the meat is definitely worth it!  Service: Everyone was super friendly and attentive. The servers were patient and cook for you all the way through for each meat which was nice. Sometimes I just prefer to cook it myself so I can eat and chat since having them cook in between us gets kind of awkward. One thing to point out is that they don't serve us individual plates. After the meat was cooked, they move it to the side of the grill and we had no plates to hold the meat except eating off of the grill. There was also no napkins to be found. We were always checked up on except it gradually slowed when the dining area got busier which was understandable.   Overall, I enjoyed my experience here at Goong. It is a nice place to take friends and family to for the finer dining KBBQ experience than the typical places around Chinatown. I will come back and order the party platters next time to try out all the different kinds of meat they offer!

q67ZZL4ndgrXg6CGEICQRA.text: We just finished eating at Goong for the first time, and it certainly will not be our last visit there. The atmosphere is very low key and the staff are very attentive. We had one of the large combinations, beef and pork, and they served each of us a bowl of rice, and a bowl of marinated onions. We had 13 other side servings (I believe it was 13...it was a ton of food), along with our beef and pork. The cost for the entire thing was $85. That served 4-5 people, and yes, it was a great value and a ton of delicious food. The server grills your meat right at the table, and sets it to the side of the gill when it is done. Everything was top notch. And the staff couldn't have been more hospitable and attentive. You do have the option of sitting in a traditional booth, or removing your shoes and sitting on pillows on the floor. We chose the traditional booth setting. They serve Bori Cha (a traditional barely tea) so we didn't opt for anything else to drink. They also end the meal with a delicious cinnamon tea. There was no rush to our experience...everything was low key and considerate. We highly recommend Goong.

W-4rnoKcUByDTHDCKuGx6w.text: Was about to go Soyo when I passed this place and it caught my eye. After reading the reviews of this place, it seemed like a legit place for some good KBBQ. I didn't have expectations that it will surpass Kang Hodong in LA, but was expecting at least close in par with Hobak here in town. The bonchon was superb, they brought over 16 different items, and all of them more or less is very good. No complaints there. But unfortunately, that was actually the highlights of my time here.  We got the beef combo, which consist of 5 plates of meat. Each plate has a small amount, but the quantity even though not as much as Hobak, is more than enough for 2 and perhaps decent enough for even 3. The meat themselves all seemed high quality, they're all thinly sliced and looked fresh enough. However, it's not really about how good the meat is but it's how you cook it right? Out of my favorite places on the west coast, Kang Hodong in LA and Hobak in Vegas, they all cook for you, making sure you don't screw up the beautiful meat in the process. This place claimed to cook for you when I sat down, but they seem to leave for a long time after putting down the meat, and by the time they come back, the meat is already over cooked. It's not like it was crowded when I got there, there was only 1 other table at the time. I asked for medium rare, and the 1st 3 plates were all medium well to well done, which just in my experience ruin the reason to eat KBBQ.   Also, unlike most other KBBQ places, this place use unmarinated meats. Most places I've had unmarinated meats have to be absolutely superb to pull it off. I went to this place in Matsuzakagyu Yakiniku M in Osaka, and they pulled it off perfectly. I don't think you can pull unmarinated meats unless you have the perfect meats, otherwise you should just stick to marinated meats. Hobak does not pretend that they have the perfect meats, and even with imperfect meats they manage to pull off amazing tastes. They also do better soybean paste soup and the steamed eggs.   From the decor of this place, which mind you is VERY well done, to the unmarinated meats, to the service, I feel like this establishment is pretending to be something it's not. There's nothing that stands out either completely great or completely terrible about this place. However, I've definitely spent less money at other places for a more enjoyable KBBQ meal. It's a shame that my first experience wasn't a more satisfactory one, but I was certainly hoping it to surprise me. Perhaps my expectations were too high.

krotqyAHiuUlbR2WN5SmiA.text: This place was really good! We went on a recommendation from my best foodie yelp elite Korean friend so I figured it would be a good bet. The atmosphere wasn't my favorite (a little bright and sterile) but the food was good. They went buck wild on the sides with what we ordered (the pork and beef combo) such that our table didn't even fit everything. They had to stack some items on the top of our booth backs. It was awesome! Everything was super fresh and delicious. My favorite was the ribeye and pork belly (as usual) and honestly the only I didn't like were the marinated meats that ended the meal. The marinated beef was sooo sweet and the marinated pork was so flavored you vouldnt even taste the meat. That's just personal preference though. When I go back (and I definitely will) j will opt out of those meats and double up on something else.   We had to ask for garlic and jalapenos and gochujang and sesame oil (again personal preference, but some places do bring it automatically) but they were more than happy to supply it.   Overall a good experience. It doesn't hold a candle to Donday and Yakiniku Seoul in Waikiki but that's okay ;)

1g1uZiOhSNxpDd6_1AL_5Q.text: Items Selected: Barley Tea Banchan - Fish Cakes, Kimchee, Jalapeno Radish Soup, Vegetable Cakes, Spicy Eggplant, Potato Salad, Simple Salad, Soy Noodles, Pickled Vegetables, Soy, Salt, etc. Chadolbagi - Thinly Sliced Prime Brisket Galbi - Marinated Prime Short Rib Hangjeongsal - Pork Jowl Jaengban Guksu - Cold Buckwheat Noodles with Vegetables and Hardboiled Egg Dolsot Bibimbap - White Rice, Stir-fried Vegetables, Marinated Beef, Fried Egg, Spicy Sauce Tteok Manduguk - Soup with Rice Cakes and Dumplings in Beef Stock  Not one for all-you-can-eat restaurants, especially the sort where "cooking your own food" is considered the norm, it was with hopes of dispelling such misconceptions that a seat was taken at Goong Korean BBQ on South Rainbow, two friends with far more experience at such places providing great conversation and a whole lot of education during the meal's nearly-two hour span.  Considered to be one of the city's more authentic experiences, shoes removed and decorative-pads provided for seating at one of several gas-fired grilltops, those arriving at Goong during lunch hours are likely to be struck by the tranquility of a space devoid of televisions or elaborate decorations, the clean lines complimented by a light soundtrack as servers provide menus and beverages while speaking in hushed tones.  Offering several lunch specials alongside the dinner menu, a la carte Meats as well as party-sized Combos offered alongside a variety of Soups and Rice plates, it was with both Korean and English descriptions that choices spread across several pages, the ordering deferred to others with some input as to a Rice Cake Soup and Pork Jowls that sounded particularly interesting.  Partially familiar with the format, a plethora of small bowls and plates quickly flooding the table prior to the first Meat selection, it was with small bites tasted of each Banchan that the palate was prepared for the flavors to follow, the Fish Cakes and Spicy Eggplant particularly memorable as makeshift appetizers while choices like the pickled Daikon, Onions and Soy Noodles were better utilized with the Proteins, or at least as palate cleansers between bites.  Turning focus now to the grill, a total of three Meats ordered with a second helping of Galbi proving far superior to the sinewy first round, those making their first visit to Goong would be well advised to order at least one plate of the thinly-sliced Chadolbagi that cooks through in under two-minutes as well as a Pork plate, the glass cases in back proudly displaying the sort of quality worth paying for as each is sliced to order in a nothing-to-hide way.  Not one for really hot stuff, even Goong's Kimchee a bit too heated if not taken with some rice, additional plates tasted included the Cold Buckwheat Noodle Salad served with Soy and lava-red Sauce as well as the comforting Dolsot Bibimbap, a large bowl of Tteok Manduguk presented last with Salt and Pepper by a server who all but admitted gauging his table's "whiteness" even though the overstuffed Dumplings in Beef Stock were already savory enough.  ***  An enjoyable meal as much for the company as for the food, Goong Korean BBQ proved a nice introduction to a new genre, though the service did feel slightly judgmental throughout the course of the afternoon while prices trend higher than would be anticipated for several of the dinner Rice Bowls, Soups and Casseroles.  Also, Mochi is not dessert...

LJzZDTrFxalm46j2K_CZfw.text: Can service be too...attentive?   I love that the restaurant is spacious, clean and modern. Love the many sides they give and the quality of the meat, this and Hobak definitely have the best meat quality in all of the Korean BBQ places and decent pricing too.   But I was so annoyed being there, to the point where I could not have a conversation with my friend. We had about 4 different servers taking care of us... you would think this is awesome and service should be beyond expectations..but no.   It was my first time there so I needed time to look over the menu, I asked the first server to give us some time, then 2 other servers came by wanting to take our order so we had to ask for more time again.   Then my friend wanted pictures of some of the dishes so we told one of the servers that we can cook the meat ourselves, she let us be but the other servers kept coming by asking us if we are sure we want to do it ourselves. Then my friend wanted to cut the pork belly before it was fully cooked so it can cook more quickly, but a server came by and rudely asked "You cutting before its cooked?" - then he took over with the meat and told us "Don't cut ok?!" ... Seriously?!? We asked to be left alone... and they keep coming over acting like we don't know how to grill meat. The same guy came back and keep cooking our meats and was putting meat that I did not want onto my plate so he can cook more meat...they kept coming over and being in our faces we had to stop our conversation every time they come by.   I get it that they are trying to give you good service, they are trying to cook the meat for us and its really nice of them... But they should let us be when we ASKED for it multiple times. My friend and I prefer to cook our own meat so we can eat at our own pace... these servers kept coming by and cooking meat continuously and we felt rushed to eat them all before they are over-cooked.   They really should not have too many people working the same table, and they clearly don't communicate with each other since we had to repeat ourselves multiple times. The staff here are way too aggressive...it is as if they get annoyed that you are cooking your own meat!   I really enjoyed the food, best meat quality and a great variety of side dishes. But when I have a meal, I like to be able to talk to my friends, I like to eat at my own pace and I generally like to be left alone so I could comfortably eat. This place is way too aggressive with their serving style and they are borderline rushing you to finish your meal and being rude.

un-f8ks7OyM4Vp44AxaV4A.text: Came here with a friend on a Monday evening, easy to find, off of Rainbow and Robindale, behind Dairy Queen. New place i heard about recently like another on Spring Mtn.   Decor is amazing and quite different from any other KBBQ place in town. Very clean and open. I noticed they had those "floor seats" where you have to take off your shoes and put your legs in a hole areas for larger groups. Nice quiet ambiance. "Older style" hoods up in the air causing the smoke to NOT go in and get exhausted (rip)   Service was pretty immediate and friendly. Very attentive and they cook for you as well.   My friend wanted the pork platter so we had ordered that  Pork Platter ($42 - Good for 2-3 people) - Consists of Pork Belly, Pork Jowl, Marinated Pork Outside Skirt, and Spicy Marinated Thinly Sliced Pork  Combination platters come with steamed egg and a choice of soup (kimchi, doenjang [bean paste], or soft tofu)   Other combinations they have are  Beef Platter ($65 - Good for 2-3 people) - Consists of Prime Rib Eye, Wagyu Top Sirloin, Prime Chuck Flat, Prime Flat Iron, Thinly Sliced Prime Brisket, Marinated Thinly Sliced Ribeye  Beef & Pork Platter ($85 - Good for 4-5 people) Consists of Prime Rib Eye, Wagyu Top Sirloin, Prime Chuck Flat, Thinly Sliced Prime Brisket, Pork Belly, Spicy Marinated Thinly Sliced Pork, Marinated Thinly Sliced Rib Eye  Goong Special ($145 - Good for 4-5 people) Consists of Wagyu Rib Eye, Wagyu Top Sirloin, Prime Boneless Short Rib, Wagyu Chuck Flat, Prime Flat Iron, Pork Belly, Pork Jowl, Marinated Prime Short Ribs, Black Tiger Shrimp  They do have individual options too to order (BBQ, Marinated BBQ, various entrees,   First of all. TONS OF SIDE DISHES ! We were two people in a booth, we almost had our entire table covered in side dishes and what not. Didn't even have our own individual plate/bowl for eating. Lol xD Sliced pickled daikon, potato salad, onion salad in light sauce, jap chae, fish cake, romaine sesame oil dressed salad, black beans, spicy raw octopus, kimchi, chives, iceburg lettuce salad, and a plate of seaweed, carrot and cucumber sticks with a small bowl of gochujang. Each person also gets a dish of green tea salt and normal salt and pepper, and a dish of sauce  Like another place in town, i believe they have their own butchering to provide such a vast variety of meats AND be able to serve raw beef (one of their dishes consisting of julienned raw beef marinated with salt, garlic and sesame oil - needs to be super fresh meat to do this)  ------------------------------------------ they have different grills for different meats. Pork tends to be the flat metal plate vs Beef being a more open grate   Pork belly and pork jowl came out first and was cooked first. Service was very attentive that neither side were burnt and was flipped constantly. Pork especially with lots of fat tends to burn fast later on but none were. Beautifully cooked. Tender and juicy.   Marinated Pork Outside Skirt was nicely done. Not overly flavorful. Fairly light. Tender and juicy. Awkward various sizes on some pieces but im not too picky about that.   Spicy Marinated Thinly Sliced Pork is like the normal spicy pork but sliced thinner. Cooked fairly fast too.   ----------------------------------------- Service was very attentive. It was a slow night. If they can keep this up even when they are busy, that would be amazing  I did notice as we were leaving that one of the waiters were up and cleaning the hoods. I noticed how clean the bottom of the grill was prior to cooking. Maybe they clean each individual one after use? Would be nice if they cook uphold that AND keep it going.   Definitely would come back to try the beef.

3kf8mN3k0x0ZbB67bfZxCQ.text: We went here randomly because we did not want to drive to hobak. I had come when they first opened for lunch and it was great.   I was hesitant to go for dinner because the prices were high but I knew their meat was of superior quality. My boyfriend and I were extremely pleased more than we expected. The large amount of sides immediately made me happy. Their staff was very attentive and nice (which is not common for Asian restaurants) The staff cooked our meats according to our preferences and changed our grill when necessary. The grill heats up super fast too. (I am a bit impatient during grill changes but this was not a concern). I also liked the fact that I got to chose the type of soup we wanted. I love tofu soup and it was probably one of the most flavorful broth that I have ever had in Las Vegas.   I cannot say that they are better than Hobak because the experience was entirely different but both places are great.  (I might like this place better). It is very clean and welcoming, there are different areas depending on your group size and it is very well ventilated. We might have left smelling a little like kbbq but honestly, we could go out after leaving and people wouldn't know. I love this place.

Imqn5rbhIQEHYub9nPNOfQ.text: Location: the place was easy to find. It's partnered with a lot of Asian restaurants that are one by one person.  The parking is somewhat limited so you'll have to find parking elsewhere, if it's too packed.   Environment: everything inside was well organized.  Nothing too flashy.   Food and service: the food was pretty good for the price. We ordered the beef set and seafood pancake. The food came on time and was not over cooked or left to dry. The quality of beef was great for the price. The banchan served was good quality except the fish cake. A bit too soggy for me. But asides from that everything was made with good flavor.   Bathroom: clean and modern. Single stall with a urinal for the men and 2 stalls for the women's bathroom   Overall, surprisingly good food and service. I'm surprised it wasn't as busy for a weekend . Definitely a must go.

pJrEm8ypOVIHqlV0OXUS6w.text: Con: The restaurant does not adhere to their hours. My fiance and I came here one night around 10PM. We walked in with another group and both were seated at the same time.  We sat there for over ten minutes and no one greeted us. There were several workers surrounding us cleaning up for the night. Although they list longer hours, it appeared that they were ready to shut down. We got up and walked out and no one said anything. It was pretty apparent that they wanted us to leave.   Pro: We decided to give this place another shot and came in around 7PM. I am SO GLAD that we did. The quality of the food is incredible!! It is probably the highest quality Korean BBQ we have had in all of Vegas. The prices are well worth it! They insist on cooking the food for you as opposed to other Korean BBQ restaurants that allow you to do it yourself. Given that this is my fiance's favorite part of the experience, he asked if they would mind allowing him to cook it himself to which they said no problem. They did pop over every now and then to offer tips. They also wanted us to move faster than we were (not sure why) but we insisted that we wanted to take our time. Overall, the service was great and the food was delicious. Can't wait to return!!!

Ka0En7jd-Dahl5N0p5qNrw.text: The food is delicious and the service is first rate.  Love this place!!  We had the beef platter. Lots of food including soup and sides.  The food was very fresh and well prepared.

OAXqNg65iLFE_PNREMdrAw.text: it's the best Korean BBQ I 've seen. I really like the handmade peach soju here. I would come back here to try this restaurant

myunBOMRFavj1eAxYfppVw.text: First visit. Staff friendly and attentive. Had chic beef and pork. Marinated very tender and flavorful. Sides were well balanced.

bBAOwisiXdhenpiLOQCKyA.text: The food was fine, but the iced green tea and the chai tea at the end were fabulous.  Worth sitting through a lunch with music blasting and slow service.

_reJnVs9FeKiBUF8_d_0tQ.text: So sad to see this place turn to crap!  We've been going to Goong since it first opened and have always raved about the place. My husband and I have our date night one a month at Goong and we've always loved the food and the service. Well, the service is still good but the food has really gone downhill. For the last three times we've gone, slowly but surely they started eliminating some of the side dishes (namely the Korean potato salad and then the green papaya salad), then the meat portions started getting smaller and smaller, and finally, the quality of the meat was just awful on our last visit. We always order the Wagyu top sirloin and the tenderloin and they were terrible: fatty, gristled, really tough to chew.  We complained to our server who just smiled (yes, I said smiled) and did nothing to correct the problems.  She never offered to replace the bad meat, or offer us other side dishes, she just smiled and walked away.  Maybe a language issue????  Needless to say, we won't be back. Sorry Goong, three strikes and you're out.

N3J_ldrt-4IpuFfY5NK29g.text: We thought this restaurant looked great aesthetically, but after waiting 5 min to be seated (per their sign) and then waiting another 10 minutes to order I walked out of the restaurant. Two people who were seated across and sat down way after us got to order their food from someone we didn't even know was a waiter. (This supposed waiter gave us a complimentary beverage and that's it. This employee saw us waiting for a waiter and did nothing). That's when we walked out of the restaurant. I don't know if they were short staffed or what? Unprofessional!!!!!!!! I really wanted Korean food too. Never returning here. I'll stick with Sura, Honey pig and Gen instead. So for lunch we went to Omoide which is across from them and received professional and attentive service.

Z8Q5xUcAQ6NAFwCXbp_n5Q.text: First time having Korean BBQ ... Couldn't have picked a better place for a rookie's first time.  Thank you Goong, your service was awesome!

6sDXj5ZmDP2QjfS-2ifMzg.text: First time eating Korean  BBQ here in Las Vegas and it was really good! Service was great very friendly!! We got our food quickly and the staff was attentive. We will be coming back!

BLh2IgDu2-HQdX5VoPu_cQ.text: Second visit on a Sunday night.  The place is full of Koreans which is always a good sign! My wife and I agree the best Korean spot in Vegas hands down!  The quality of meat is as good a high end steakhouse! It was busy when we walked in but were seated right away.  We had to wait a bit to place our order but that was ok because they were clearly busy.  The nice thing is everyone who walked by our table asked how we were doing and if we needed anything. Great service and awesome Korean BBQ.  We will be back.

xpRaZS9JaDBtDr2KhxtZAw.text: We are visiting Las Vegas and wanted to have lunch away from the busy strip, so we googled "best places to eat in Vegas" and this was part of the 25 hottest places to eat in Vegas and so we went....we  ordered the beef platter and...... it makes you not want to go to any other Korean BBQ place but this one....that says a lot considering that we live in Los Angeles and we are surrounded by Korean BBQ places in every city around LA....quality of the food and meat is excellent and the service and atmosphere is top notch and if you do decode to visit this place don't forget to try the mochi my wife says its the best she's ever tasted....this place also offers an authentic Korean restaurant feel ( the effect of sitting on a low table) and its not to far from the Las Vegas strip (about 10-15 mins away)..... Would highly recommend.

y6sRYozoTPBDBa_pQf0wqg.text: I love this place! First time trying Korean BBQ and it is my go to! My boyfriend and I always order the calbi and kimjijie! Our server Eun Sung was awesome as well as everyone else!

j2oDlpY8O0HMe20nzyXOKg.text: Came here with one other person. Wagyu beef was excellent quality. The service was very fast. We were never left waiting for food, and the servers also assisted in cooking our meat while we were eating. Recommended to try!

Z33ZGKB_7FBidxJkV5GmvA.text: Best quality of meat I've ever eaten in a Korean restaurant. Excellent. Definitely try the Wagyu ribeye. The kalbi was perfectly marinated. The banchan selection was wide and delicious. The ambience was very relaxing. This is my new favorite Korean spot!

LwoOPGgdvQI6ORyZf4oEjg.text: This restaurant is better than the ones in LA!!!  Lots of ban chan.  Good bbq, we had beef and pork bulgogi.  Both really good, I never eat the pork bbq, but I think it was better than the beef.  Really nice place and the staff are really nice and attentive.  Found my new favorite spot!

GXJv9bYMcSzNv3DHtnY0Ww.text: Went to Goong last week.  It's a beautiful restaurant!  The quality of meat was great.  But when we first walked into the restaurant, we asked the host to seat our party at a regular table so that my husband's sore back could rest in a normal chair.  The host said ok, but continued to lead us to the traditional Korean tables saying that my husband could rest his back on the end booth of the traditional seating area.  He made us take off our shoes, as well, in order to sit in the traditional seating area.  Not wanting to be a downer to the party, we conceded.  However, the last thing I wanted to do right before I ate was touch my shoes.  Anyway, the wait staff was very nice and explained our cuts of meat.  However, I do not like having the waiters continuously interrupting our dinner conversations to explain the meat and cook it for us.  I prefer we cook it ourselves.  We will probably not go back.

f6W1vuWtsmMyNtuHdSJ1Mg.text: It's really traditional korean restaurant. We love it a lot! The food here us very fresh and tasty! We specially like the beef and pork combination platter~ The people here are really kind and friendly. We will definitely come here again for sure :)
